Esther Waters

by

GEORGE MOORE

1899

I

She (Esther) stood on the platform watching the receding train. A few bushes hid the curve of the line; the white vapour rose above them, evaporating in the pale evening. A moment more and the last carriage would pass out of sight. The white gates swung forward slowly and closed over the line.

An oblong box painted reddish brown and tied with a rough rope lay on the seat beside her (Esther). The movement of her (Esther) back and shoulders showed that the bundle she (Esther) carried was a heavy one, the sharp bulging of the grey linen cloth that the weight was dead. She (Esther) wore a faded yellow dress and a black jacket too warm for the day. A girl of twenty, short, strongly built, with short, strong arms. Her (girl) neck was plump, and her (girl) hair of so ordinary a brown that it passed unnoticed. The nose was too thick, but the nostrils were well formed. The eyes were grey, luminous, and veiled with dark lashes. But it was only when she (girl) laughed that her (girl) face lost its habitual expression, which was somewhat sullen; then it flowed with bright humour. She (girl) laughed now, showing a white line of almond-shaped teeth. The porter had asked her (girl) if she (girl) were afraid to leave her (girl) bundle with her (girl) box. Both, he (porter) said, would go up together in the donkey-cart. The donkey-cart came down every evening to fetch parcels... That was the way to Woodview, right up the lane. She (girl) could not miss it. She (girl) would find the lodge gate in that clump of trees. The man lingered, for she (girl) was an attractive girl, but the station-master called him (man) away to remove some luggage.

It was a barren country. Once the sea had crawled at high tide half-way up the sloping sides of those downs. It would do so now were it not for the shingle bank which its surging had thrown up along the coast. Between the shingle bank and the shore a weedy river flowed and the little town stood clamped together, its feet in the water's edge. There were decaying shipyards about the harbour, and wooden breakwaters stretched long, thin arms seawards for ships that did not come. On the other side of the railway apple blossoms showed above a white-washed wall; some market gardening was done in the low-lying fields, whence the downs rose in gradual ascents. On the first slope there was a fringe of trees. That was Woodview.

The girl gazed on this bleak country like one who saw it for the first time. She (girl) saw without perceiving, for her (girl) mind was occupied with personal consideration. She (girl) found it difficult to decide whether she (girl) should leave her (girl) bundle with her (girl) box. It hung heavy in her (girl) hand, and she (girl) did not know how far Woodview was from the station. At the end of the platform the station-master took her (girl) ticket, and she (girl) passed over the level-crossing still undecided. The lane began with iron railings, laurels, and French windows. She (girl) had been in service in such houses, and knew if she (girl) were engaged in any of them what her (girl) duties would be. But the life in Woodview was a great dream, and she (girl) could not imagine herself accomplishing all that would be required of her (girl). There would be a butler, a footman, and a page; she (girl) would not mind the page--but the butler and footman, what would they think? There would be an upper-housemaid and an under-housemaid, and perhaps a lady's-maid, and maybe that these ladies had been abroad with the family. She (maid) had heard of France and Germany. Their conversation would, no doubt, turn on such subjects. Her (maid) silence would betray her (maid). They would ask her (maid) what situations she (maid) had been in, and when they learned the truth she (maid) would have to leave disgraced. She (maid) had not sufficient money to pay for a ticket to London. But what excuse could she (maid) give to Lady Elwin, who had rescued her (maid) from Mrs. Dunbar and got her (maid) the place of kitchen-maid at Woodview? She (maid) must not go back. Her (maid) father would curse her (maid), and perhaps beat her (maid) mother and her (maid) too. Ah! he (father) would not dare to strike her (maid) again, and the girl's face flushed with shameful remembrance. And her (maid) little brothers and sisters would cry if she (maid) came back. They had little enough to eat as it was. Of course she (maid) must not go back. How silly of her (maid) to think of such a thing!

She (maid) smiled, and her (maid) face became as bright as the month: it was the first day of June. Still she (maid) would be glad when the first week was over. If she (maid) had only a dress to wear in the afternoons! The old yellow thing on her (maid) back would never do. But one of her (maid) cotton prints was pretty fresh; she (maid) must get a bit of red ribbon--that would make a difference. She (maid) had heard that the housemaids in places like Woodview always changed their dresses twice a day, and on Sundays went out in silk mantles and hats in the newest fashion. As for the lady's-maid, she (maid) of course had all her (maid) mistress's clothes, and walked with the butler. What would such people think of a little girl like her (girl)! Her (girl) heart sank at the thought, and she (girl) sighed, anticipating much bitterness and disappointment. Even when her (girl) first quarter's wages came due she (girl) would hardly be able to buy herself a dress: they would want the money at home. Her (girl) quarter's wages! A month's wages most like, for she (girl)'d never be able to keep the place. No doubt all those fields belonged to the Squire, and those great trees too; they must be fine folk, quite as fine as Lady Elwin--finer, for she (Elwin) lived in a house like those near the station.

On both sides of the straight road there were tall hedges, and the nursemaids lay in the wide shadows on the rich summer grass, their perambulators at a little distance. The hum of the town died out of the ear, and the girl continued to imagine the future she (girl) was about to enter on with increasing distinctness. Looking across the fields she (girl) could see two houses, one in grey stone, the other in red brick with a gable covered with ivy; and between them, lost in the north, the spire of a church. On questioning a passer-by she (girl) learnt that the first house was the Rectory, the second was Woodview Lodge. If that was the lodge, what must the house be?

Two hundred yards further on the road branched, passing on either side of a triangular clump of trees, entering the sea road; and under the leaves the air was green and pleasant, and the lungs of the jaded town girl drew in a deep breath of health. Behind the plantation she (girl) found a large white-painted wooden gate. It opened into a handsome avenue, and the gatekeeper told her (girl) to keep straight on, and to turn to the left when she (girl) got to the top. She (girl) had never seen anything like it before, and stopped to admire the uncouth arms of elms, like rafters above the roadway; pink clouds showed through, and the monotonous dove seemed the very heart of the silence.

Her (girl) doubts returned; she (girl) never would be able to keep the place. The avenue turned a little, and she (girl) came suddenly upon a young man leaning over the paling, smoking his (man) pipe.

``Please sir, is this the way to Woodview?'' (unknown)

``Yes, right up through the stables, round to the left.'' (he)
Then, noticing the sturdily-built figure, yet graceful in its sturdiness, and the bright cheeks, he (man) said,
``You look pretty well done; that bundle is a heavy one, let me hold it for you.'' (he)

``I am a bit tired,'' (she)
she (girl) said, leaning the bundle on the paling.
``They told me at the station that the donkey-cart would bring up my box later on.'' (unknown)

``Ah, then you are the new kitchen-maid? What's your name?'' (unknown)

``Esther Waters.'' (unknown)

``My mother's the cook here; you'll have to mind your p's and q's or else you'll be dropped on. The devil of a temper while it lasts, but not a bad sort if you don't put her (Esther) out.'' (unknown)

``Are you in service here?'' (unknown)

``No, but I hope to be afore long. I could have been two years ago, but mother did not like me to put on livery, and I don't know how I'll face her (mother) when I come running down to go out with the carriage.'' (unknown)

``Is the place vacant?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
Esther asked, raising her (Esther) eyes timidly, looking at him (man) sideways.

``Yes, Jim Story got the sack about a week ago. When he (Story) had taken a drop he (Story)'d tell every blessed thing that was done in the stables. They'd get him (Story) down to the

``Red Lion' for the purpose; of course the squire couldn't stand that.'' (unknown)

``And shall you take the place?'' (unknown)

``Yes. I'm not going to spend my life carrying parcels up and down the King's Road, Brighton, if I can squeeze in here. It isn't so much the berth that I care about, but the advantages, information fresh from the fountain-head. You won't catch me chattering over the bar at the

``Red Lion' and having every blessed word I say wired up to London and printed next morning in all the papers.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther wondered what he (man) was talking about, and, looking at him (man), she (Esther) saw a low, narrow forehead, a small, round head, a long nose, a pointed chin, and rather hollow, bloodless cheeks. Notwithstanding the shallow chest, he (man) was powerfully built, the long arms could deal a swinging blow. The low forehead and the lustreless eyes told of a slight, unimaginative brain, but regular features and a look of natural honesty made William Latch a man that ten men and eighteen women out of twenty would like.

``I see you have got books in that bundle,'' (he)
he (Latch) said at the end of a long silence.
``Fond of readin'?'' (unknown)

``They are mother's books,'' (she)
she (Esther) replied, hastily.
``I was afraid to leave them at the station, for it would be easy for anyone to take one out, and I should not miss it until I undid the bundle.'' (unknown)

``Sarah Tucker--that's the upper-housemaid--will be after you to lend them to her (Tucker). She (Tucker) is a wonderful reader. She (Tucker) has read every story that has come out in _Bow Bells_ for the last three years, and you can't puzzle her (Tucker), try as you will. She (Tucker) knows all the names, can tell you which lord it was that saved the girl from the carriage when the `osses were tearing like mad towards a precipice a `undred feet deep, and all about the baronet for whose sake the girl went out to drown herself in the moonlight, I `aven't read the books mesel', but Sarah and me are great pals,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther trembled lest he (Latch) might ask her (Esther) again if she (Esther) were fond of reading; she (Esther) could not read. Noticing a change in the expression of her (Esther) face, he (Latch) concluded that she (Esther) was disappointed to hear that he (Latch) liked Sarah and regretted his (Latch) indiscretion.

``Good friends, you know--no more. Sarah and me never hit it off; she (Sarah) will worry me with the stories she (Sarah) reads. I don't know what is your taste, but I likes something more practical; the little `oss in there, he (I) is more to my taste.'' (he)
Fearing he (Latch) might speak again of her (Sarah) books, she (Sarah) mustered up courage and said--

``They told me at the station that the donkey-cart would bring up my box.'' (she)

``The donkey-cart isn't going to the station to-night--you'll want your things, to be sure. I'll see the coachman; perhaps he (I) is going down with the trap. But, golly! it has gone the half-hour. I shall catch it for keeping you talking, and my mother has been expecting you for the last hour. She (mother) hasn't a soul to help her (mother), and six people coming to dinner. You must say the train was late.'' (unknown)

``Let us go, then,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
cried Esther.
``Will you show me the way?'' (unknown)

Over the iron gate which opened into the pleasure-ground, thick branches of evergreen oaks made an arch of foliage, and between the trees a glimpse was caught of the angles and urns of an Italian house--distant about a hundred yards. A high brick wall separated the pleasure-ground from the stables, and as William and Esther turned to the left and walked up the roadway he (William) explained that the numerous buildings were stables. They passed by many doors, hearing the trampling of horses and the rattling of chains. Then the roadway opened into a handsome yard overlooked by the house, the back premises of which had been lately rebuilt in red brick. There were gables and ornamental porches, and through the large kitchen windows the servants were seen passing to and fro. At the top of this yard was a gate. It led into the park, and, like the other gate, was overhung by bunched evergreens. A string of horses came towards this gate, and William ran to open it. The horses were clothed in grey cloth. They wore hoods, and Esther noticed the black round eyes looking through the eyelet holes. They were ridden by small, ugly boys, who swung their little legs, and struck them with ash plants when they reached their heads forward chawing at the bits. When William returned he (William) said,

``Look there, the third one; that's he (I)--that's Silver Braid.'' (he)

An impatient knocking at the kitchen window interrupted his (William) admiration, and William, turning quickly, said,

``Mind you say the train was late; don't say I kept you, or you'll get me into the devil of a pickle. This way.'' (William/William Latch)
The door let into a wide passage covered with coconut matting. They walked a few yards; the kitchen was the first door, and the handsome room she (Esther) found herself in did not conform to anything that Esther had seen or heard of kitchens. The range almost filled one end of the room, and on it a dozen saucepans were simmering; the dresser reached to the ceiling, and was covered with a multitude of plates and dishes. Esther thought how she (Esther) must strive to keep it in its present beautiful condition, and the elegant white-capped servants passing round the white table made her (Esther) feel her (Esther) own insignificance.

``This is the new kitchen-maid, mother.'' (unknown)

``Ah, is it indeed?'' (she)
said Mrs. Latch looking up from the tray of tartlets which she (Esther) had taken from the oven and was filling with jam. Esther noticed the likeness that Mrs. Latch bore to her (Latch) son. The hair was iron grey, and, as in William's face, the nose was the most prominent feature.

``I suppose you'll tell me the train was late?'' (unknown)

``Yes, mother, the train was a quarter of an hour late,'' (William/William Latch)
William chimed in.

``I didn't ask you, you idle, lazy, good-for-nothing vagabond. I suppose it was you who kept the girl all this time. Six people coming to dinner, and I've been the whole day without a kitchen-maid. If Margaret Gale hadn't come down to help me, I don't know where we should be; as it is, the dinner will be late.'' (The housemaids)

The two housemaids, both in print dresses, stood listening. Esther's face clouded, and when Mrs. Latch told her (Latch) to take her (Latch) things off and set to and prepare the vegetables, so that she (Latch) might see what she (Latch) was made of, Esther did not answer at once. She (Esther) turned away, saying under her (Esther) breath,

``I must change my dress, and my box has not come up from the station yet.'' (She)

``You can tuck your dress up, and Margaret Gale will lend you her (Gale) apron.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther hesitated.

``What you've got on don't look as if it could come to much damage. Come, now, set to.'' (The housemaids)

The housemaids burst into loud laughter, and then a sullen look of dogged obstinacy passed over and settled on Esther's face, even to the point of visibly darkening the white and rose complexion.

II

A sloping roof formed one end of the room, and through a broad, single pane the early sunlight fell across a wall papered with blue and white flowers. Print dresses hung over the door. On the wall were two pictures--a girl with a basket of flowers, the coloured supplement of an illustrated newspaper, and an old and dilapidated last century print. On the chimney-piece there were photographs of the Gale family in Sunday clothes, and the green vases that Sarah had given Margaret on her (Sarah) birthday.

And in a low, narrow iron bed, pushed close against the wall in the full glare of the sunlight, Esther lay staring half-awake, her (Esther) eyes open but still dim with dreams. She (Esther) looked at the clock. It was not yet time to get up, and she (Esther) raised her (Esther) arms as if to cross them behind her (Esther) head, but a sudden remembrance of yesterday arrested her (Esther) movement, and a sudden shadow settled on her (Esther) face. She (Esther) had refused to prepare the vegetables. She (Esther) hadn't answered, and the cook had turned her (Esther) out of the kitchen. She (Esther) had rushed from the house under the momentary sway of hope that she (Esther) might succeed in walking back to London; but William had overtaken her (Esther) in the avenue, he (William) had expostulated with her (Esther), he (William) had refused to allow her (Esther) to pass. She (Esther) had striven to tear herself from him (William), and, failing, had burst into tears. However, he (William) had been kind, and at last she (Esther) had allowed him (William) to lead her (Esther) back, and all the time he (William) had filled her (Esther) ears with assurances that he (William) would make it all right with his (William) mother. But Mrs. Latch had closed her (Esther) kitchen against her (Esther), and she (Esther) had had to go to her (Esther) room. Even if they paid her (Esther) fare back to London, how was she (Esther) to face her (Esther) mother? What would father say? He (father) would drive her (Esther) from the house. But she (Esther) had done nothing wrong. Why did cook insult her (Esther)?

As she (Esther) pulled on her (Esther) stockings she (Esther) stopped and wondered if she (Esther) should awake Margaret Gale. Margaret's bed stood in the shadow of the obliquely falling wall; and she (Margaret) lay heavily, one arm thrown forward, her (Margaret) short, square face raised to the light. She (Margaret) slept so deeply that for a moment Esther felt afraid. Suddenly the eyes opened, and Margaret looked at her (Margaret) vaguely, as if out of eternity. Raising her (Margaret) hands to her (Margaret) eyes she (Margaret) said--

``What time is it?'' (she)

``It has just gone six.'' (unknown)

``Then there's plenty of time; we needn't be down before seven. You get on with your dressing; there's no use in my getting up till you are done--we'd be tumbling over each other. This is no room to put two girls to sleep in--one glass not much bigger than your hand. You'll have to get your box under your bed... In my last place I had a beautiful room with a Brussels carpet, and a marble washstand. I wouldn't stay here three days if it weren't--'' (The girl)
The girl laughed and turned lazily over.

Esther did not answer.

``Now, isn't it a grubby little room to put two girls to sleep in? What was your last place like?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther answered that she (Esther) had hardly been in service before. Margaret was too much engrossed in her (Margaret) own thoughts to notice the curtness of the answer.

``There's only one thing to be said for Woodview, and that is the eating; we have anything we want, and we'd have more than we want if it weren't for the old cook: she (it) must have her (it) little bit out of everything and she (it) cuts us short in our bacon in the morning. But that reminds me! You have set the cook against you; you'll have to bring her (it) over to your side if you want to remain here.'' (unknown)

``Why should I be asked to wash up the moment I came in the house, before even I had time to change my dress.'' (unknown)

``It was hard on you. She (it) always gets as much as she (it) can out of her (it) kitchen-maid. But last night she (it) was pressed, there was company to dinner. I'd have lent you an apron, and the dress you had on wasn't of much account.'' (unknown)

``It isn't because a girl is poor--'' (Margaret/Margaret Gale/Gale)

``Oh, I didn't mean that; I know well enough what it is to be hard up.'' (Margaret/Margaret Gale/Gale)
Margaret clasped her (Margaret) stays across her (Margaret) plump figure and walked to the door for her (Margaret) dress. She (Margaret) was a pretty girl, with a snub nose and large, clear eyes. Her (Margaret) hair was lighter in tone than Esther's, and she (Esther) had brushed it from her (Esther) forehead so as to obviate the defect of her (Esther) face, which was too short.

Esther was on her (Esther) knees saying her (Esther) prayers when Margaret turned to the light to button her (Margaret) boots.

``Well, I never!'' (she)
she (Margaret) exclaimed.
``Do you think prayers any good?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther looked up angrily.

``I don't want to say anything against saying prayers, but I wouldn't before the others if I was you--they'll chaff dreadful, and call you Creeping Jesus.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Margaret, I hope they won't do anything so wicked. But I am afraid I shan't be long here, so it doesn't matter what they think of _me_.'' (Margaret/Margaret Gale/Gale)

When they got downstairs they opened the windows and doors, and Margaret took Esther round, showing her (Margaret) where the things were kept, and telling her (Margaret) for how many she (Margaret) must lay the table. At that moment a number of boys and men came clattering up the passage. They cried to Esther to hurry up, declaring that they were late. Esther did not know who they were, but she (Esther) served them as best she (Esther) might. They breakfasted hastily and rushed away to the stables; and they had not been long gone when the squire and his (squire) son Arthur appeared in the yard. The Gaffer, as he (Gaffer) was called, was a man of about medium height. He (Gaffer) wore breeches and gaiters, and in them his (Gaffer) legs seemed grotesquely thick. His (Gaffer) son was a narrow-chested, undersized young man, absurdly thin and hatchet-faced. He (Gaffer) was also in breeches and gaiters, and to his (Gaffer) boots were attached long-necked spurs. His (Gaffer) pale yellow hair gave him (Gaffer) a somewhat ludicrous appearance, as he (Gaffer) stood talking to his (Gaffer) father, but the moment he (Gaffer) prepared to get into the saddle he (Gaffer) seemed quite different. He (Gaffer) rode a beautiful chestnut horse, a little too thin, Esther thought, and the ugly little boys were mounted on horses equally thin. The squire rode a stout grey cob, and he (squire) watched the chestnut, and was also interested in the brown horse that walked with its head in the air, pulling at the smallest of all the boys, a little freckled, red-headed fellow.

``That's Silver Braid, the brown horse, the one that the Demon is riding; the chestnut is Bayleaf, Ginger is riding him (Demon): he (Demon) won the City and Suburban. Oh, we did have a fine time then, for we all had a bit on. The betting was twenty to one, and I won twelve and six pence. Grover won thirty shillings. They say that John--that's the butler--won a little fortune; but he (butler) is so close no one knows what he (butler) has on. Cook wouldn't have anything on; she (Grover) says that betting is the curse of servants--you know what is said, that it was through betting that Mrs. Latch's husband got into trouble. He (husband) was steward here, you know, in the late squire's time.'' (Margaret/Margaret Gale/Gale)

Then Margaret told all she (Margaret) had heard on the subject. The late Mr. Latch had been a confidential steward, and large sums of money were constantly passing through his (steward) hands for which he (steward) was never asked for any exact account. Contrary to all expectation, Marksman was beaten for the Chester Cup, and the squire's property was placed under the charge of a receiver. Under the new management things were gone into more closely, and it was then discovered that Mr. Latch's accounts were incapable of satisfactory explanation. The defeat of Marksman had hit Mr. Latch as hard as it had hit the squire, and to pay his (squire) debts of honour he (squire) had to take from the money placed in his (squire) charge, confidently hoping to return it in a few months. The squire's misfortunes anticipated the realization of his (squire) intentions; proceedings were threatened, but were withdrawn when Mrs. Latch came forward with all her (Latch) savings and volunteered to forego her (Latch) wages for a term of years. Old Latch died soon after, some lucky bets set the squire on his (squire) legs again, the matter was half forgotten, and in the next generation it became the legend of the Latch family. But to Mrs. Latch it was an incurable grief, and to remove her (Latch) son from influences which, in her (Latch) opinion, had caused his (son) father's death, Mrs. Latch had always refused Mr. Barfield's offers to do something for William. It was against her (Latch) will that he (William) had been taught to ride; but to her (Latch) great joy he (William) soon grew out of all possibility of becoming a jockey. She (Latch) had then placed him (William) in an office in Brighton; but the young man's height and shape marked him (man) out for livery, and Mrs. Latch was pained when Mr. Barfield proposed it.

``Why cannot they leave me my son?'' (she)
she (Latch) cried; for it seemed to her (Latch) that in that hateful cloth, buttons and cockade, he (Barfield) would be no more her (Latch) son, and she (Latch) could not forget what the Latches had been long ago.

``I believe there's going to be a trial this morning,'' (Margaret/Margaret Gale/Gale)
said Margaret;
``Silver Braid was stripped--you noticed that--and Ginger always rides in the trials.'' (Margaret/Margaret Gale/Gale)

``I don't know what a trial is,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther.
``They are not carriage-horses, are they? They look too slight.'' (unknown)

``Carriage-horses, you ninny! Where have you been to all this while--can't you see that they are race-horses?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther hung down her (Esther) head and murmured something which Margaret didn't catch.

``To tell the truth, I didn't know much about them when I came, but then one never hears anything else here. III

Esther was one of the Plymouth Brethren. In their chapel, if the house in which they met could be called a chapel, there were neither pictured stories of saints, nor vestments, nor music, nor even imaginative stimulant in the shape of written prayers. Her (Esther) knowledge of life was strictly limited to her (Esther) experience of life; she (Esther) knew no drama of passion except that which the Gospels relate: this story in the _Family Reader_ was the first representation of life she (Esther) had met with, and its humanity thrilled her (Esther) like the first idol set up for worship. The actress told Norris that she (actress) loved him (Norris). They were on a balcony, the sky was blue, the moon was shining, the warm scent of the mignonette came up from the garden below, the man was in evening dress with diamond shirt studs, the actress's arm was large and white. They had loved each other for years. The strangest events had happened for the purpose of bringing them together, and, fascinated against her (actress) will, Esther could not but listen. But at the end of the chapter the racial instinct forced reproval from her (Esther).

``I am sure it is wicked to read such tales.'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)

``You shouldn't be here at all. Can't Mrs. Latch find nothing for you to do in the scullery?'' (Grover/Miss Grover)

said Sarah, awaking to a sense of the situation,

She (Esther) asked why they should take pleasure in torturing her (Esther). It was not her (Esther) fault if she (Esther) did not know how to read. Even the names she (Esther) could not read, and the shame of her (Esther) ignorance lay upon her (Esther) heavier than a weight of lead.

Esther Waters came from Barnstaple. She (Waters) had been brought up in the strictness of the Plymouth Brethren, and her (Waters) earliest memories were of prayers, of narrow, peaceful family life. This early life had lasted till she (Waters) was ten years old. Then her (Waters) father died. He (father) had been a house-painter, but in early youth he (father) had been led into intemperance by some wild companions. He (father) was often not in a fit state to go to work, and one day the fumes of the beer he (father) had drunk overpowered him (father) as he (father) sat in the strong sunlight on his (father) scaffolding. In the hospital he (father) called upon God to relieve him (father) of his (father) suffering; then the Brethren said,

``You never thought of God before. Be patient, your health is coming back; it is a present from God; you would like to know Him (God) and thank Him (God) from the bottom of your heart?'' (Plymouth Brethren/Brethren)

John Waters' heart was touched. He (Waters) became one of the Brethren, renouncing those companions who refused to follow into the glory of God. His (God) conversion and subsequent grace won for him (God) the sympathies of Mary Thornby. But Mary's father would not consent to the marriage unless John abandoned his (John) dangerous trade of house-painter. John Waters consented to do this, and old James Thornby, who had made a competence in the curiosity line, offered to make over his (Waters) shop to the young couple on certain conditions; these conditions were accepted, and under his (Waters) father-in-law's direction John drove a successful trade in old glass, old jewellery, and old furniture.

The Brethren liked not this trade, and they often came to John to speak with him (John) on the subject, and their words were--

``Of course this is between you and the Lord, but these things'' (him)
-LRB-pointing to the old glass and jewellery-RRB-
``often are but snares for the feet, and lead weaker brethren into temptation. Of course, it is between you and the Lord.'' (him)

So John Waters was tormented with scruples concerning the righteousness of his (Waters) trade, but his (Waters) wife's gentle voice and eyes, and the limitations that his (Waters) accident, from which he (Waters) had never wholly recovered, had set upon his (Waters) life, overruled his (Waters) scruples, and he (Waters) remained until he (Waters) died a dealer in artistic ware, eliminating, however, from his (Waters) dealings those things to which the Brethren most strongly objected.

When he (Waters) died his (Waters) widow strove to carry on the business, but her (widow) father, who was now a confirmed invalid, could not help her (widow). In the following year she (widow) lost both her (widow) parents. Many changes were taking place in Barnstaple, new houses were being built, a much larger and finer shop had been opened in the more prosperous end of the town, and Mrs. Waters found herself obliged to sell her (widow) business for almost nothing, and marry again. Children were born of this second marriage in rapid succession, the cradle was never empty, and Esther was spoken of as the little nurse.

Her (Esther) great solicitude was for her (Esther) poor mother, who had lost her (Esther) health, whose blood was impoverished by constant child-bearing. Mother and daughter were seen in the evenings, one with a baby at her (Mother) breast, the other with an eighteen months old child in her (Mother) arms. Esther did not dare leave her (Esther) mother, and to protect her (Esther) she (Esther) gave up school, and this was why she (Esther) had never learnt how to read.

One of the many causes of quarrel between Mrs. Saunders and her (Saunders) husband was her (Saunders) attendance at prayer-meetings when he (husband) said she (Saunders) should be at home minding her (Saunders) children. He (husband) used to accuse her (Saunders) of carrying on with the Scripture-readers, and to punish her (Saunders) he (husband) would say,

``This week I'll spend five bob more in the public--that'll teach you, if beating won't, that I don't want none of your hypocritical folk hanging round my place.'' (he)
So it befell the Saunders family to have little to eat; and Esther often wondered how she (Esther) should get a bit of dinner for her (Esther) sick mother and her (Esther) hungry little brothers and sisters. Once they passed nearly thirty hours without food. She (Esther) called them round her (Esther), and knelt down amid them: they prayed that God might help them; and their prayers were answered, for at half-past twelve a Scripture lady came in with flowers in her (lady) hands. She (lady) asked Mrs. Saunders how her (lady) appetite was. Mrs. Saunders answered that it was more than she (Saunders) could afford, for there was nothing to eat in the house. Then the Scripture lady gave them eighteen pence, and they all knelt down and thanked God together.

But although Saunders spent a great deal of his (God) money in the public-house, he (God) rarely got drunk and always kept his (God) employment. He (God) was a painter of engines, a first-rate hand, earning good money, from twenty-five to thirty shillings a week. He (God) was a proud man, but so avaricious that he (God) stopped at nothing to get money. He (God) was an ardent politician, yet he (God) would sell his (God) vote to the highest bidder, and when Esther was seventeen he (God) compelled her (Esther) to take service regardless of the character of the people or of what the place was like. They had left Barnstaple many months, and were now living in a little street off the Vauxhall Bridge Road, near the factory where Saunders worked; and since they had been in London Esther had been constantly in service. Why should he (God) keep her (Esther)? She (Esther) wasn't one of his (God) children, he (God) had quite enough of his (God) own. Sometimes of an evening, when Esther could escape from her (Esther) drudgery for a few minutes, her (Esther) mother would step round, and mother and daughter, wrapped in the same shawl, would walk to and fro telling each other their troubles, just as in old times. But these moments were few. In grimy lodging-houses she (mother) worked from early morning till late at night, scrubbing grates, preparing bacon and eggs, cooking chops, and making beds. She (mother) had become one of those London girls to whom rest, not to say pleasure, is unknown, who if they should sit down for a few moments hear the mistress's voice,

``Now, Eliza, have you nothing to do, that you are sitting there idle?'' (the mistress)

The ambitious members of the Barfield family declared that the marriage was social ruin, but more dispassionate critics called it a very suitable match; for it was not forgotten that three generations ago the Barfields were livery-stable keepers; they had risen in the late squire's time to the level of county families, and the envious were now saying that the Barfield family was sinking back whence it came.

IV

Esther's position in Woodview was now assured, and her (Esther) fellow-servants recognised the fact, though they liked her (Esther) none the better for it. Mr. Leopold's press! For forty years no one had looked into that press. Mr. Leopold guarded it from every gaze, but it seemed to be a much-varied repository from which, if he (Leopold) chose, he (Leopold) could produce almost any trifle that might be required. It seemed to combine the usefulness of a hardware shop and a drug store.

The pantry had its etiquette and its discipline. Jockey boys were rarely admitted, unless with the intention of securing their services for the cleaning of boots or knives. The simplest human sentiments were abiding principles in Esther--love of God, and love of God in the home. Then the race-horses were always going to or coming from the downs. He (Demon) was about to start for Portslade and back, wrapped, as he (Demon) would put it, in a red-hot scorcher of an overcoat.

She (Esther) had taken a rope as if she (Esther) were going to hang herself, and having fastened it to a branch, she (Esther) had knelt down as if she (Esther) were saying her (Esther) prayers. He (them) had burst into tears and Esther had felt sorry for him (them), and almost inclined to marry him (them) out of pity for his (them) forlorn condition.

Her (Esther) life grew happier and happier. She (Esther) forgot that Mrs. Latch would not teach her (Latch) how to make jellies, and had grown somewhat used to Sarah's allusions to her (Sarah) ignorance. She (Sarah) was still very poor, had not sufficient clothes, and her (Sarah) life was full of little troubles; but there were compensations. So Esther's life grew and was fashioned; so amid the ceaseless round of simple daily occupations mistress and maid learned to know and to love one another, and became united and strengthful in the tender and ineffable sympathies of race and religion.

Mr. Leopold's desires looked as if they were going to be fulfilled. The heavens seemed to have taken the fortunes of the stable in hand. Rain fell generally in the afternoon and night, leaving the mornings fine, and Silver Braid went the mile gaily, becoming harder and stronger. And in the intermittent swish of showers blown up from the sea Woodview grew joyous, and a conviction of ultimate triumph gathered and settled on every face except Mrs. Barfield's and Mrs. Latch's. And askance they looked at the triumphant little butler. He (butler) became more and more the topic of conversation. He (butler) seemed to hold the thread of their destiny in his (butler) press. Peggy was especially afraid of him (butler).

``I like to know things for the pleasure of talking about them, but he (Gaffer) for the pleasure of holding his (Gaffer) tongue.'' (the lady)
Peggy was Miss Margaret Barfield, a cousin, the daughter of a rich brewer.

A furtive and clandestine little man, ashamed of his (man) women-folk and keeping them out of sight as much as possible. His (man) wife a pale, dim woman, tall as he (man) was short, preserving still some of the graces of the lady's-maid, shy either by nature or by the severe rule of her (maid) lord, always anxious to obliterate herself against the hedges when you met her (maid) in the lane or against the pantry door when any of the family knocked to ask for hot water, or came with a letter for the post. ``Can I do anything for you, Mr. Arthur?'' (Mr. Leopold)

Every day, a little before twelve, Mr. Leopold went out for his (Leopold) morning walk; every day if it were fine you would meet him (Leopold) at that hour in the lane either coming from or going to Shoreham. For thirty years he (Leopold) had done his (Leopold) little constitutional, always taking the same road, always starting within a few minutes of twelve, always returning in time to lay the cloth for lunch at half-past one. ``Red Lion,'' (children)

VI

The boys were playing ball in the stables, but she (Esther) did not feel as if she (Esther) wanted to romp with them. There was a stillness and a sweetness abroad which penetrated and absorbed her (Esther). She (Esther) moved towards the paddock gate; the pony and the donkey came towards her (Esther), and she (Esther) rubbed their muzzles in turn. It was a pleasure to touch anything, especially anything alive. She (Esther) even noticed that the elm trees were strangely tall and still against the calm sky, and the rich odour of some carnations which came through the bushes from the pleasure-ground excited her (Esther); the scent of earth and leaves tingled in her (Esther), and the cawing of the rooks coming home took her (Esther) soul away skyward in an exquisite longing; she (Esther) was, at the same time, full of romantic love for the earth, and of a desire to mix herself with the innermost essence of things. The beauty of the evening and the sea breeze instilled a sensation of immortal health, and she (Esther) wondered if a young man came to her (Esther) as young men came to the great ladies in Sarah's books, how it would be to talk in the dusk, seeing the bats flitting and the moon rising through the branches.

The family was absent from Woodview, and she (Esther) was free to enjoy the beauty of every twilight and every rising moon for still another week. But she (Esther) wearied for a companion. Sarah and Grover were far too grand to walk out with her (Sarah); and Margaret had a young man who came to fetch her (Margaret), and in their room at night she (Margaret) related all he (man) had said. But for Esther there was nothing to do all the long summer evenings but to sit at the kitchen window sewing. Her (Esther) hands fell on her (Esther) lap, and her (Esther) heart heaved a sigh of weariness. In all this world there was nothing for her (Esther) to do but to continue her (Esther) sewing or to go for a walk on the hill. She (Esther) was tired of that weary hill! But she (Esther) could not sit in the kitchen till bedtime. She (Margaret) did not think that any young man would bother much about her (Margaret). Happening at that moment to look round, she (Margaret) saw a man coming through the hunting gate. ``Trying to find Sarah,'' (she)
she (Margaret) thought.

She (Margaret) was glad of the chance to get a mouthful of fresh air, and they went towards the hunting gate. William held it open and she (Margaret) passed through.

The plantations were enclosed by a wooden fence, and beyond them the bare downs rose hill after hill. On the left the land sloped into a shallow valley sown with various crops; and the shaws about Elliot's farm were the last trees. Beyond the farmhouse the downs ascended higher and higher, treeless, irreclaimable, scooped into long patriarchal solitudes, thrown into wild crests.

There was a smell of sheep in the air, and the flock trotted past them in good order, followed by the shepherd, a huge hat and a crook in his (crook) hand, and two shaggy dogs at his (crook) heels. A brace of partridges rose out of the sainfoin, and flew down the hills; and watching their curving flight Esther and William saw the sea under the sun-setting, and the string of coast towns.

``A lovely evening, isn't it?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther acquiesced; and tempted by the warmth of the grass they sat down, and the mystery of the twilight found way into their consciousness.

``We shan't have any rain yet awhile.'' (unknown)

``How do you know?'' (unknown)

``I'll tell you,'' (William/William Latch)
William answered, eager to show his (William) superior knowledge.

``No, I can see nothing,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

For something to say, and hoping to please, Esther asked him (William) where the race-course was.

``There, over yonder. I can't show you the start, a long way behind that hill, Portslade way; then they come right along by that gorse and finish up by Truly barn--you can't see Truly barn from here, that's Thunder's barrow barn; they go quite half a mile farther.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

The sheep had been folded, and seeing them lying in the greyness of this hill-side, and beyond them the massive moonlit landscape and the vague sea, Esther suddenly became aware, as she (Esther) had never done before, of the exceeding beauty of the world. Looking up in William's face, she (Esther) said--

``Oh, how beautiful!'' (she)

The conversation wandered agreeably, and they became more conscious of each other. They left the farm and wandered on the high road until a stile leading to a cornfield beguiled and then delayed their steps.

The silence of the moonlight was clear and immense; and they listened to the trilling of the nightingale in the copse hard by. First they sought to discover the brown bird in the branches of the poor hedge, and then the reason of the extraordinary emotion in their hearts. It seemed that all life was beating in that moment, and they were as it were inflamed to reach out their hands to life and to grasp it together. Even William noticed that. And the moon shone on the mist that had gathered on the long marsh lands of the foreshore. Beyond the trees the land wavered out into down land, the river gleamed and intensely.

This moment was all the poetry of their lives. The striking of a match to light his (William) pipe, which had gone out, put the music to flight, and all along the white road he (William) continued his (William) monologue, interrupted only by the necessity of puffing at his (William) pipe.

``Mother says that if I had twopence worth of pride in me I wouldn't have consented to put on the livery; but what I says to mother is, ``What's the use of having pride if you haven't money?'' I tells her (their) that I am rotten with pride, but my pride is to make money. I can't see that the man what is willing to remain poor all his (man) life has any pride at all... But, Lord! I have argued with mother till I'm sick; she (mother) can see nothing further than the livery; that's what women are--they are that short-sighted... ''--that's what I said to her (mother). I saw well enough there was nothing for me but service, and I means to stop here until I can get on three or four good things and then retire into a nice comfortable public-house and do my own betting.'' (I. pride mother)

``You would give up betting then?'' (unknown)

``I'd give up backing `orses, if you mean that... What I should like would be to get on to a dozen good things at long prices--half-a-dozen like Silver Braid would do it. For a thousand or fifteen hundred pounds I could have the ``Red Lion,

'' and just inside my own bar I could do a hundred-pound book on all the big races.'' (the Red Lion)

``Red Lion,'' (he)

VII

The Barfield calculation was that they had a stone in hand. Bayleaf, Mr. Leopold argued, would be backed to win a million of money if he (Leopold) were handicapped in the race at seven stone; and Silver Braid, who had been tried again with Bayleaf, and with the same result as before, had been let off with only six stone.

More rain had fallen, the hay-crop had been irretrievably ruined, the prospects of the wheat harvest were jeopardized, but what did a few bushels of wheat matter? Another pound of muscle in those superb hind-quarters was worth all the corn that could be grown between here and Henfield. Let the rain come down, let every ear of wheat be destroyed, so long as those delicate fore-legs remained sound. These were the ethics that obtained at Woodview, and within the last few days showed signs of adoption by the little town and not a few of the farmers, grown tired of seeing their crops rotting on the hill-sides. The fever of the gamble was in eruption, breaking out in unexpected places--the station-master, the porters, the flymen, all had their bit on, and notwithstanding the enormous favouritism of two other horses in the race--Prisoner and Stoke Newington--Silver Braid had advanced considerably in the betting. Reports of trials won had reached Brighton, and not more than five-and-twenty to one could now be obtained.

The discovery that the Demon had gone up several pounds in weight had introduced the necessary alloy into the mintage of their happiness; the most real consternation prevailed, and the strictest investigation was made as to when and how he (Demon) had obtained the quantities of food required to produce such a mass of adipose tissue. Then the Gaffer had the boy upstairs and administered to him (Gaffer) a huge dose of salts, seeing him (Gaffer) swallow every drop; and when the effects of the medicine had worn off he (Gaffer) was sent for a walk to Portslade in two large overcoats, and was accompanied by William, whose long legs led the way so effectively. On his (William) return a couple of nice feather beds were ready, and Mr. Leopold and Mr. Swindles themselves laid him (Swindles) between them, and when they noticed that he (Swindles) was beginning to cease to perspire Mr. Leopold made him (Leopold) a nice cup of hot tea.

``That's the way the Gaffer used to get the flesh off in the old days when he (Gaffer) rode the winner at Liverpool.'' (unknown)

``It's the Demon's own fault,'' (Mr. Swindles)
said Mr. Swindles;
``if he (Demon) hadn't been so greedy he (Demon) wouldn't have had to sweat, and we should `ave been spared a deal of bother and anxiety.'' (Mr. Swindles)

``Greedy!'' (the boy)
murmured the little boy, in whom the warm tea had induced a new perspiration;
``I haven't had what you might call a dinner for the last three months. I think I'll chuck the whole thing.'' (the boy)

``Not until this race is over,'' (Mr. Swindles)
said Mr. Swindles.

Mr. Leopold strove to engage the Demon's attention with compliments regarding his (Leopold) horsemanship in the City and Sub. while Mr. Swindles raised the bedclothes.

Mr. Leopold and Mr. Swindles exchanged glances. It was clear they thought that there was something in the last words of the fainting Demon, and the pan was withdrawn. VIII

The great day was now fast approaching, and the Gaffer had promised to drive his (Gaffer) folk in a drag to Goodwood. No more rain was required, the colt's legs remained sound, and three days of sunshine would make all the difference in their sum of happiness. In the kitchen Mrs. Latch and Esther had been busy for some time with chickens and pies and jellies, and in the passage there were cases packed with fruit and wine. The dressmaker had come from Worthing, and for several days the young ladies had not left her (Esther). ``You'll be late! You'll be late!'' (gentlemen)

At that moment Sarah and Grover entered the kitchen talking loudly. They asked Mrs. Latch how soon they could have dinner--the sooner the better, for the Saint had told them that they were free to go out for the day. They were to try to be back before eight, that was all. Ah! the Saint was a first-rate sort. She (Latch) had said that she (Latch) did not want anyone to attend on her (Latch). She (Latch) would, get herself a bit of lunch in the dining-room. Mrs. Latch allowed Esther to hurry on the dinner, and by one o'clock they had all finished. Sarah and Margaret were going into Brighton to do some shopping, Grover was going to Worthing to spend the afternoon with the wife of one of the guards of the Brighton and South Coast Railway. Mrs. Latch went upstairs to lie down. So it grew lonelier and lonelier in the kitchen. Esther's sewing fell out of her (Esther) hands, and she (Esther) wondered what she (Esther) should do. She (Esther) thought that she (Esther) might go down to the beach, and soon after she (Esther) put on her (Esther) hat and stood thinking, remembering that she (Esther) had not been by the sea, that she (Esther) had not seen the sea since she (Esther) was a little girl. But she (Esther) remembered the tall ships that came into the harbour, sail falling over sail, and the tall ships that floated out of the harbour, sail rising over sail, catching the breeze as they went aloft--she (Esther) remembered them.

A suspension bridge, ornamented with straight-tailed lions, took her (Esther) over the weedy river, and having crossed some pieces of rough grass, she (Esther) climbed the shingle bank. The heat rippled the blue air, and the sea, like an exhausted caged beast, licked the shingle. Sea-poppies bloomed under the wheels of a decaying bathing-machine, and Esther wondered. But the sea here was lonely as a prison, and, seeing the treeless coast with its chain of towns, her (Esther) thoughts suddenly reverted to William. She (Esther) wished he (William) were with her (Esther), and for pleasant contemplation she (Esther) thought of that happy evening when she (Esther) saw him (William) coming through the hunting gate, when, his (William) arm about her (Esther), William had explained that if the horse won she (Esther) would take seven shillings out of the sweepstakes. She (Esther) knew now that William did not care about Sarah; and that he (William) cared for her (Sarah) had given a sudden and unexpected meaning to her (Sarah) existence. She (Sarah) lay on the shingle, her (Sarah) day-dream becoming softer and more delicate as it rounded into summer sleep.

And when the light awoke her (Sarah) she (Sarah) saw flights of white clouds--white up above, rose-coloured as they approached the west; and when she (Sarah) turned, a tall, melancholy woman.

``Good evening, Mrs. Randal,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther, glad to find someone to speak to.
``I've been asleep.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I'm the kitchen-maid. They've gone to the races; there was nothing to do, so I came down here.'' (Mrs. Randal)

Mrs. Randal's lips moved as if she (Randal) were going to say something. But she (Randal) did not speak. Soon after she (Randal) rose to her (Randal) feet.

``I think that it must be getting near tea-time; I must be going. You might come in and have a cup of tea with me, if you're not in a hurry back to Woodview.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther was surprised at so much condescension, and in silence the two women crossed the meadows that lay between the shingle bank and the river. Trains were passing all the while, scattering, it seemed, in their noisy passage over the spider-legged bridge, the news from Goodwood. The news seemed to be borne along shore in the dust, and, as if troubled by prescience of the news, Mrs. Randal said, as she (Randal) unlocked the cottage door--

``It is all over now. The people in those trains know well enough which has won.'' (she)

``Yes, I suppose they know, and somehow I feel as if I knew too. I feel as if Silver Braid had won.'' (Mrs. Randal)

Mrs. Randal's home was gaunt as herself. Everything looked as if it had been scraped, and the spare furniture expressed a meagre, lonely life. She (Randal) dropped a plate as she (Randal) laid the table, and stood pathetically looking at the pieces. When Esther asked for a teaspoon she (Esther) gave way utterly.

``I haven't one to give you; I had forgotten that they were gone. I should have remembered and not asked you to tea.'' (unknown)

``I should have remembered and not asked you back to tea; but I was so miserable, and it is so lonely sitting in this house, that I could stand it no longer... Talking to you saved me from thinking, and I did not want to think until this race was over. If Silver Braid is beaten we are ruined. Indeed, I don't know what will become of us. For fifteen years I have borne up; I have lived on little at the best of times, and very often have gone without; but that is nothing compared to the anxiety--to see him (us) come in with a white face, to see him (us) drop into a chair and hear him (us) say, ``Beaten a head on the post,'' or ``Broke down, otherwise he (us) would have won in a canter.'' I have always tried to be a good wife and tried to console him (it), and to do the best when he (it) said, ``I have lost half a year's wages, I don't know how we shall pull through.'' I have borne with ten thousand times more than I can tell you. The sufferings of a gambler's wife cannot be told. Tell me, what do you think my feelings must have been when one night I heard him (gambler) calling me out of my sleep, when I heard him (gambler) say, ``I can't die, Annie, without bidding you good-bye. I can only hope that you will be able to pull through, and I know that the Gaffer will do all he (Gaffer) can for you, but he (Gaffer) has been hit awful hard too. You mustn't think too badly of me, Annie, but I have had such a bad time that I couldn't put up with it any longer, and I thought the best thing I could do would be to go.

'' That's just how he (gambler) talked--nice words to hear your husband speak in your ear through the darkness! There was no time to send for the doctor, so I jumped out of bed, put the kettle on, and made him (doctor) drink glass after glass of salt and water. At last he (doctor) brought up the laudanum.'' (I)

Esther listened to the melancholy woman, and remembered the little man whom she (Esther) saw every day so orderly, so precise, so sedate, so methodical, so unemotional, into whose life she (Esther) thought no faintest emotion had ever entered--and this was the truth.

``So long as I only had myself to think of I didn't mind; but now there are the children growing up. He (Gaffer) should think of them. Heaven only knows what will become of them... John is as kind a husband as ever was if it weren't for that one fault; but he (John) cannot resist having something on any more than a drunkard can resist the bar-room.'' (unknown)

``Winner, winner, winner of the Stewards' Cup!'' (The women)

IX

Nearly everything came down untouched. Eating and drinking had been in progress almost all day on the course, and Esther had finished washing up before nine, and had laid the cloth in the servants' hall for supper. But if little was eaten upstairs, plenty was eaten downstairs; the mutton was finished in a trice, and Mrs. Latch had to fetch from the larder what remained of a beefsteak pudding. Even then they were not satisfied, and fine inroads were made into a new piece of cheese. Beer, according to orders, was served without limit, and four bottles of port were sent down so that the health of the horse might be adequately drunk.

While assuaging their hunger the men had exchanged many allusive remarks regarding the Demon's bad ending, how nearly he (Demon) had thrown the race away; and the meal being now over, and there being nothing to do but to sit and talk, Mr. Leopold, encouraged by William, entered on an elaborate and technical account of the race. The women listened, playing with a rind of cheese, glancing at the cheese itself, wondering if they could manage another slice, and the men sipping their port wine, puffing at their pipes, William listening most avidly of all, enjoying each sporting term, and ingeniously reminding Mr. Leopold of some detail whenever he (Leopold) seemed disposed to shorten his (Leopold) narrative. The criticism of the Demon's horsemanship took a long while, for by a variety of suggestive remarks William led Mr. Leopold into reminiscences of the skill of certain famous jockeys in the first half of the century. These digressions wearied Sarah and Grover, and their thoughts wandered to the dresses that had been worn that day, and the lady's-maid remembered she (maid) would hear all that interested her (maid) that night in the young ladies' rooms. At last, losing all patience, Sarah declared that she (Sarah) didn't care what Chifney had said when he (William) just managed to squeeze his (William) horse's head in front in the last dozen yards, she (Sarah) wanted to know what the Demon had done to so nearly lose the race--had he (Demon) mistaken the winning-post and pulled up? William looked at her (Sarah) contemptuously, and would have answered rudely, but at that moment Mr. Leopold began to tell the last instructions that the Gaffer had given the Demon. The orders were that the Demon should go right up to the leaders before they reached the half-mile, and remain there. Of course, if he (Demon) found that he (Demon) was a stone or more in hand, as the Gaffer expected, he (Demon) might come away pretty well as he (Demon) liked, for the greatest danger was that the horse might get shut out or might show temper and turn it up.

``Well,'' (Mr. Leopold)
said Mr. Leopold,

He (Demon) said afore starting that he (Demon) felt weak; you took him (Demon) along too smartly from Portslade the last time you went there.'' (Mr. Leopold)

``When he (Demon) went by himself he (Demon)'d stop playing marbles with the boys round the Southwick public-house.'' (unknown)

``Do you think he (God) has any chance of winning the Chesterfield Cup?'' (William/William Latch)

``He (God)'ll win in a canter if he (God)'ll only run straight. If I was the Gaffer I think I'd put up a bigger boy. He (boy)'ll `ave to carry a seven-pound penalty, and Johnnie Scott could ride that weight.'' (jockey)

The likelihood that a horse will bolt with one jockey and run straight with another was argued passionately, and illustrated with interesting reminiscences drawn from that remote past when Mr. Leopold was the Gaffer's private servant--before either of them had married--when life was composed entirely of horse-racing and prize-fighting. But cutting short his (Leopold) tale of how he (Leopold) had met one day the Birmingham Chicken in a booth, and, not knowing who he (Leopold) was, had offered to fight him (Leopold), Mr. Leopold confessed he (Leopold) did not know how to act--he (Leopold) had a bet of fifty pounds to ten shillings for the double event; should he (Leopold) stand it out or lay some of it off? William thrilled with admiration. What a `ead, and who'd think it? that little `ead, hardly bigger than a cocoanut! What a brain there was inside! Fifty pounds to ten shillings; should he (William) stand it out or hedge some of it? Who could tell better than Mr. Leopold? It would, of course, be a pity to break into the fifty. What did ten shillings matter? Mr. Leopold was a big enough man to stand the racket of it even if it didn't come back. William felt very proud of being consulted, for Mr. Leopold had never before been known to let anyone know what he (Leopold) had on a race.

Old Watkins, an elderly man with white whiskers and a curving stomach, had just run in to wet his (Watkins) whistle. He (Watkins) walked back to his (Watkins) office with Mr. Leopold and William, a little corner shelved out of some out-houses, into which you could walk from the street.

He (William) had had a bet of ten shillings to one on one race and had lost; he (William) had had half-a-crown on another and had lost; in a word, three-and-sixpence had to be subtracted from his (William) winnings on Silver Braid. These amounted to more than five pounds. Should he (William) put a sovereign of his (William) winnings on Silver Braid for the Chesterfield? Mr. Leopold's business demanded more consideration. The fat betting man and the scarecrow little butler walked aside and talked, both apparently indifferent to the impatience of a number of small customers; sometimes Joey called in his (Joey) shrill cracked voice if he (Joey) might lay ten half-crowns to one, or five shillings to one, as the case might be. Watkins would then raise his (Watkins) eyes from Mr. Leopold's face and nod or shake his (Watkins) head, or perhaps would sign with his (Watkins) fingers what odds he (Watkins) was prepared to lay. With no one else would Watkins talk so lengthily, showing so much deference. Mr. Leopold had the knack of investing all he (Leopold) did with an air of mystery, and the deepest interest was evinced in this conversation. ``I'll take twelve to one--twenty-four pounds to two. Shall I book it?'' (Mr. Leopold)

Mr. Leopold shook his (Leopold) head, and, smiling enigmatically, said he (Leopold) must be getting back. William was much impressed, and congratulated himself on his (William) courage in taking the ten half-sovereigns to one. Mr. Leopold knew a thing or two; he (Leopold) had been talking to the Gaffer that morning, and if it hadn't been all right he (Leopold) would have laid off some of the money.

Next day one of the Gaffer's two-year-olds won a race, and the day after Silver Braid won the Chesterfield Cup.

The second victory of Silver Braid nearly ruined old Watkins. He (Watkins) declared that he (Watkins) had never been so hard hit; but as he (Watkins) did not ask for time and continued to draw notes and gold and silver in handfuls from his (Watkins) capacious pockets, his (Watkins) lamentations only served to stimulate the happiness of the fortunate backers, and, listening to the sweet note of self ringing in their hearts, they returned to the public-house to drink the health of the horse.

So the flood of gold continued to roll into the little town, decrepit and colourless by its high shingle beach and long reaches of muddy river. The dear gold jingled merrily in the pockets, quickening the steps, lightening the heart, curling lips with smiles, opening lips with laughter. The dear gold came falling softly, sweetly as rain, soothing the hard lives of working folk. Lives pressed with toil lifted up and began to dream again. The dear gold was like an opiate; it wiped away memories of hardship and sorrow, it showed life in a lighter and merrier guise, and the folk laughed at their fears for the morrow and wondered how they could have thought life so hard and relentless. The dear gold was pleasing as a bird on the branch, as a flower on the stem; the tune it sang was sweet, the colour it flaunted was bright.

The trade of former days had never brought the excitement and the fortune that this horse's hoofs had done. The dust they had thrown up had fallen a happy, golden shower upon Shoreham. In every corner and crevice of life the glitter appeared. That fine red dress on the builder's wife, and the feathers that the girls flaunt at their sweethearts, the loud trousers on the young man's legs, the cigar in his (man) mouth--all is Goodwood gold. It glitters in that girl's ears and on this girl's finger.

It was said that the town of Shoreham had won two thousand pounds on the race; it was said that Mr. Leopold had won two hundred; it was said that William Latch had won fifty; it was said that Wall, the coachman, had won five-and-twenty; it was said that the Gaffer had won forty thousand pounds. For ten miles around nothing was talked of but the wealth of the Barfields, and, drawn like moths to a candle, the county came to call; even the most distant and reserved left cards, others walked up and down the lawn with the Gaffer, listening to his (Gaffer) slightest word. A golden prosperity shone upon the yellow Italian house. Carriages passed under its elm-trees at every hour and swept round the evergreen oaks. Rumour said that large alterations were going to be made, so that larger and grander entertainments might be given; an Italian garden was spoken of, balustrades and terraces, stables were in course of construction, many more race-horses were bought; they arrived daily, and the slender creatures, their dark eyes glancing out of the sight holes in their cloth hoods, walked up from the station followed by an admiring and commenting crowd. Drink and expensive living, dancing and singing upstairs and downstairs, and the jollifications culminated in a servants' ball given at the Shoreham Gardens. All the Woodview servants, excepting Mrs. Latch, were there; likewise all the servants from Mr. Northcote's, and those from Sir George Preston's--two leading county families. A great number of servants had come from West Brighton, and Lancing, and Worthing --altogether between two and three hundred.

``Evening dress is indispensable'' (unknown)
was printed on the cards. The butlers, footmen, cooks, ladies' maids, housemaids, and housekeepers hoped by this notification to keep the ball select. But the restriction seemed to condemn Esther to play again the part of Cinderella.

X

A group of men turned from the circular buffet when Esther entered. Miss Mary had given her (Mary) a white muslin dress, a square-cut bodice with sleeves reaching to the elbows, and a blue sash tied round the waist. The remarks as she (Mary) passed were,

``A nice, pretty girl.'' (she)
William was waiting, and she (Mary) went away with him (William) on the hop of a vigorous polka.

Many of the dancers had gone to get cool in the gardens, but a few couples had begun to whirl, the women borne along by force, the men poising their legs into curious geometrical positions.

Mr. Leopold was very busy dragging men away from the circular buffet--they must dance whether they knew how or not.

XII

``They are just crazy about it upstairs. Ginger and the Gaffer are the worst. They say they had better sell the place and build another house somewhere else. None of the county people will call on them now--and just as they were beginning to get on so well! (unknown)

It was one afternoon at the beginning of December; Mrs. Latch had gone upstairs to lie down. Esther had drawn her (Esther) chair towards the fire. Mrs. Barfield, who had been so good to her (Barfield), and who thought so highly of her (Barfield). The avenue was full of wind and rain; the branches creaked dolefully overhead; the lane was drenched, and the bare fields were fringed with white mist, and the houses seemed very desolate by the bleak sea; and the girl's soul was desolate as the landscape. She (girl) had come to Woodview to escape the suffering of a home which had become unendurable, and she (girl) was going back in circumstances a hundred times worse than those in which she (girl) had left it, and she (girl) was going back with the memory of the happiness she (girl) had lost. XIII

When she (Esther) arrived at Victoria it was raining. She (Esther) picked up her (Esther) skirt, and as she (Esther) stepped across a puddle a wild and watery wind swept up the wet streets, catching her (Esther) full in the face.

(unknown)

``There's no bloody need for `er to shake my `and if she (Esther) don't like,'' (Jim/Jim Story)

XIV

``Service is no place for a girl who wants to live as we used to live when father was alive--no service that I've seen. I see that plain enough. One day some flannel and shirts in a window caught Mrs. Saunder's eye, and she (woman) said--

``Well, if I `aven't a spare waistcoat left just take some of yer own things. I tell yer I want beer, and I mean to have some.'' (He)

She (Esther) had done the same before, and, if needs be, she (Esther) would do so again. XV

``I wish, mother, you was going to the hospital with me; it would save a lot of expense and you'd be better cared for.'' (XV)

It was a warm day in the middle of April, a mist of green had begun in the branches of the elms of the Green Park; and in Park Lane, in all the balconies and gardens, wherever nature could find roothold, a spray of gentle green met the eye. A chill wind was blowing. Winter had returned with the night, but the instinct of spring continued in the branches. She (Esther) would have liked to have called them round her (Esther) and told them her (Esther) miserable story, so that they might profit by her (Esther) experience.

``Come, come, take my arm,'' (she)
