``and breathe hard as you are ascending the stairs. Come along, you mustn't loiter.'' (she)

On the second landing a door was thrown open, and she (sister) found herself in a room full of people, eight or nine young men and women.

``What! in there? and all those people?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther.

``Of course; those are the midwives and the students.'' (She)

She (Esther) saw that the screams she (Esther) had heard in the passage came from a bed on the left-hand side. A woman lay there huddled up. In the midst of her (woman) terror Esther was taken behind a screen by the sister who had brought her (Esther) upstairs and quickly undressed. She (Esther) was clothed in a chemise a great deal too big for her (Esther), and a jacket which was also many sizes too large. She (Esther) remembered hearing the sister say so at the time. Both windows were wide open, and as she (Esther) walked across the room she (Esther) noticed the basins on the floor, the lamp on the round table, and the glint of steel instruments.

The students and the nurses were behind her (Esther); she (Esther) knew they were eating sweets, for she (Esther) heard a young man ask the young women if they would have any more fondants. Their chatter and laughter jarred on her (Esther) nerves; but at that moment her (Esther) pains began again and she (Esther) saw the young man whom she (Esther) had seen handing the sweets approaching her (Esther) bedside.

``Oh, no, not him (people), not him (people)!'' (she)
she (Esther) cried to the nurse.
``Not him (people), not him (people)! he (people) is too young! Do not let him (people) come near me!'' (she)

They laughed loudly, and she (Esther) buried her (Esther) head in the pillow, overcome with pain and shame; and when she (Esther) felt him (man) by her (Esther) she (Esther) tried to rise from the bed.

``Let me go! take me away! Oh, you are all beasts!'' (unknown)

``Come, come, no nonsense!'' (the nurse)
said the nurse;
``you can't have what you like; they are here to learn;'' (the nurse)
and when he (man) had tried the pains she (nurse) heard the midwife say that it wasn't necessary to send for the doctor. Another said that it would be all over in about three hours' time.
``An easy confinement, I should say. The other will be more interesting...'' (unknown)
Then they talked of the plays they had seen, and those they wished to see. A discussion arose regarding the merits of a shilling novel which every one was reading, and then Esther heard a stampede of nurses, midwives, and students in the direction of the window. A German band had come into the street.

``Is that the way to leave your patient, sister?'' (the student boy)
said the student who sat by Esther's bed, a good-looking boy with a fair, plump face. Esther looked into his (student) clear blue, girl-like eyes, wondered, and turned away for shame.

The sister stopped her (sister) imitation of a popular comedian, and said,

``Oh, she (sister)'s all right; if they were all like her (sister) there'd be very little use our coming here.'' (a comedian)

``Unfortunately that's just what they are,'' (another student fellow ends)
said another student, a stout fellow with a pointed red beard, the ends of which caught the light. Esther's eyes often went to those stubble ends, and she (Esther) hated him (student) for his (student) loud voice and jocularity. One of the midwives, a woman with a long nose and small grey eyes, seemed to mock her (woman), and Esther hoped that this woman would not come near her (Esther). She (Esther) felt that she (Esther) could not bear her (Esther) touch. There was something sinister in her (Esther) face, and Esther was glad when her (Esther) favourite, a little blond woman with wavy flaxen hair, came and asked her (Esther) if she (Esther) felt better. She (Esther) looked a little like the young student who still sat by her (Esther) bedside, and Esther wondered if they were brother and sister, and then she (Esther) thought that they were sweethearts.

Soon after a bell rang, and the students went down to supper, the nurse in charge promising to warn them if any change should take place. The last pains had so thoroughly exhausted her (nurse) that she (nurse) had fallen into a doze. But she (nurse) could hear the chatter of the nurses so clearly that she (nurse) did not believe herself asleep. And in this film of sleep reality was distorted, and the unsuccessful operation which the nurses were discussing Esther understood to be a conspiracy against her (Esther) life. She (Esther) awoke, listened, and gradually sense of the truth returned to her (Esther). She (Esther) was in the hospital... The nurses were talking of some one who had died last week... That poor woman in the other bed seemed to suffer dreadfully. Would she (woman) live through it? Would she (woman) herself live to see the morning? How long the time, how fearful the place! If the nurses would only stop talking... The pains would soon begin again... It was awful to lie listening, waiting. The windows were open, and the mocking gaiety of the street was borne in on the night wind. Then there came a trampling of feet and sound of voices in the passage--the students and nurses were coming up from supper; and at the same moment the pains began to creep up from her (woman) knees. One of the young men said that her (woman) time had not come. The woman with the sinister look that Esther dreaded, held a contrary opinion. The point was argued, and, interested in the question, the crowd came from the window and collected round the disputants. The young man expounded much medical and anatomical knowledge; the nurses listened with the usual deference of women.

Suddenly the discussion was interrupted by a scream from Esther; it seemed to her (Esther) that she (Esther) was being torn asunder, that life was going from her (Esther). The nurse ran to her (nurse) side, a look of triumph came upon her (nurse) face, and she (nurse) said,

``Now we shall see who's right,'' (she)
and forthwith ran for the doctor. He (doctor) came running up the stairs; immediately silence and scientific collectedness gathered round Esther, and after a brief examination he (doctor) said, in a low whisper--

``I'm afraid this will not be as easy a case as one might have imagined. I shall administer chloroform.'' (he)

He (doctor) placed a small wire case over her (Esther) mouth and nose, and the sickly odour which she (Esther) breathed from the cotton wool filled her (Esther) brain with nausea; it seemed to choke her (Esther), and then life faded, and at every inhalation she (Esther) expected to lose sight of the circle of faces.

* * * * *

When she (Esther) opened her (Esther) eyes the doctors and nurses were still standing round her (Esther), but there was no longer any expression of eager interest on their faces. She (Esther) wondered at this change, and then out of the silence there came a tiny cry.

``What's that?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
Esther asked.

``That's your baby.'' (unknown)

``My baby! Let me see it; is it a boy or a girl?'' (unknown)

``It is a boy; it will be given to you when we get you out of the labour ward.'' (unknown)

``I knew it would be a boy.'' (a scream)
Then a scream of pain rent the stillness of the room.
``Is that the same woman who was here when I first came in? Hasn't she (woman) been confined yet?'' (unknown)

``No, and I don't think she (woman) will be till midday; she (woman)'s very bad.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

The door was thrown open, and Esther was wheeled into the passage. She (Esther) was like a convalescent plant trying to lift its leaves to the strengthening light, but within this twilight of nature the thought of another life, now in the world, grew momentarily more distinct.

``Where is my boy?'' (she)
she (Esther) said;
``give him (boy) to me.'' (she)

The nurse entered, and answered,

``Here.'' (The nurse)
A pulp of red flesh rolled up in flannel was laid alongside of her (Esther). Its eyes were open; it looked at her (Esther), and her (Esther) flesh filled with a sense of happiness so deep and so intense that she (Esther) was like one enchanted. When she (Esther) took the child in her (Esther) arms she (Esther) thought she (Esther) must die of happiness. She (Esther) did not hear the nurse speak, nor did she (Esther) understand her (Esther) when she (Esther) took the babe from her (Esther) arms and laid it alongside on the pillow, saying,
``You must let the little thing sleep, you must try to sleep yourself.'' (the babe)

Her (Esther) personal self seemed entirely withdrawn; she (Esther) existed like an atmosphere about the babe, an impersonal emanation of love. She (Esther) lay absorbed in this life of her (Esther) life, this flesh of her (Esther) flesh, unconscious of herself as a sponge in warm sea-water. She (Esther) touched this pulp of life, and was thrilled, and once more her (Esther) senses swooned with love; it was still there. She (Esther) remembered that the nurse had said it was a boy. She (Esther) must see her (Esther) boy, and her (Esther) hands, working as in a dream, unwound him (boy), and, delirious with love, she (Esther) gazed until he (boy) awoke and cried. She (Esther) tried to hush him (boy) and to enfold him (boy), but her (Esther) strength failed, she (Esther) could not help him (boy), and fear came lest he (boy) should die. She (Esther) strove to reach her (Esther) hands to him (boy), but all strength had gone from her (Esther), and his (boy) cries sounded hollow in her (Esther) weak brain. Then the nurse came and said--

``See what you have done, the poor child is all uncovered; no wonder he (boy) is crying. I will wrap him (boy) up, and you must not interfere with him (boy) again.'' (the nurse)
But as soon as the nurse turned away Esther had her (Esther) child back in her (Esther) arms. She (Esther) did not sleep. She (Esther) could not sleep for thinking of him (boy), and the long night passed in adoration.

XVII

She (Esther) was happy, her (Esther) babe lay beside her (Esther). All her (Esther) joints were loosened, and the long hospital days passed in gentle weariness. Lady visitors came and asked questions. Esther said that her (Esther) father and mother lived in the Vauxhall Bridge Road, and she (Esther) admitted that she (Esther) had saved four pounds. There were two beds in this ward, and the woman who occupied the second bed declared herself to be destitute, without home, or money, or friends. She (woman) secured all sympathy and promises of help, and Esther was looked upon as a person who did not need assistance and ought to have known better. They received visits from a clergyman. He (clergyman) spoke to Esther of God's goodness and wisdom, but his (clergyman) exhortations seemed a little remote, and Esther was sad and ashamed that she (Esther) was not more deeply stirred. Had it been her (Esther) own people who came and knelt about her (Esther) bed, lifting their voices in the plain prayers she (Esther) was accustomed to, it might have been different; but this well-to-do clergyman, with his (clergyman) sophisticated speech, seemed foreign to her (Esther), and failed to draw her (Esther) thoughts from the sleeping child.

The ninth day passed, but Esther recovered slowly, and it was decided that she (Esther) should not leave the hospital before the end of the third week. She (Esther) knew that when she (Esther) crossed the threshold of the hospital there would be no more peace for her (Esther); and she (Esther) was frightened as she (Esther) listened to the never-ending rumble of the street. She (Esther) spent whole hours thinking of her (Esther) dear mother, and longing for some news from home, and her (Esther) face brightened when she (Esther) was told that her (Esther) sister had come to see her (Esther).

``Jenny, what has happened; is mother very bad?'' (unknown)

``Mother is dead, that's what I've come to tell you; I'd have come before, but--'' (unknown)

``Mother dead! Oh, no, Jenny! Oh, Jenny, not my poor mother!'' (unknown)

``Yes Esther. I knew it would cut you up dreadful; we was all very sorry, but she (Esther)'s dead. She (Esther)'s dead a long time now, I was just a-going to tell you--'' (unknown)

``Jenny, what do you mean? Dead a long time?'' (unknown)

``Well, she (Jenny) was buried more than a week ago. We were so sorry you couldn't be at the funeral. We was all there, and had crape on our dresses and father had crape on his (father) `at. We all cried, especially in church and about the grave, and when the sexton threw in the soil it sounded that hollow it made me sob. Julia, she (Julia) lost her (Julia) `ead and asked to be buried with mother, and I had to lead her (mother) away; and then we went `ome to dinner.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Jenny, our poor mother gone from us for ever! How did she (mother) die? Tell me, was it a peaceful death? Did she (mother) suffer?'' (unknown)

``There ain't much to tell. Mother was taken bad almost immediately after you was with us the last time. Mother was that bad all the day long and all night too we could `ardly stop in the `ouse; it gave one just the creeps to listen to her (Mother) crying and moaning.'' (unknown)

``And then?'' (unknown)

``Why, then the baby was born. It was dead, and mother died of weakness; prostration the doctor called it.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther hid her (Esther) face in the pillow. Jenny waited, and an anxious look of self began to appear on the vulgar London street face.

``Look `ere, Esther, you can cry when I've gone; I've a deal to say to yer and time is short.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Jenny, don't speak like that! Father, was he (Father) kind to mother?'' (unknown)

One of the neighbours came in to look after mother, and at last she (mother) had the doctor.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
Esther looked at her (Esther) sister through streaming tears, and the woman in the other bed alluded to the folly of poor women being confined
``in their own `omes--in a `ome where there is a drunken `usband, and most `omes is like that nowadays.'' (women)

At that moment Esther's baby awoke crying for the breast. The little lips caught at the nipple, the wee hand pressed the white curve, and in a moment Esther's face took that expression of holy solicitude which Raphael sublimated in the Virgin's downward-gazing eyes. Jenny watched the gluttonous lips, interested in the spectacle, and yet absorbed in what she (Jenny) had come to say to her (Jenny) sister.

``Your baby do look `ealthy.'' (unknown)

``Please God, my baby shall never want for anything as long as I can work for him (God). But, Jenny, my trouble will be a lesson to you. I hope you will always be a good girl, and never allow yourself to be led away; you promise me?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I promise.'' (unknown)

``A `ome like ours, a drunken father, and now that poor mother is gone it will be worse than ever. Jenny, you are the eldest and must do your best to look after the younger ones, and as much as possible to keep father from the public-house. I shall be away; the moment I'm well enough I must look out for a place.'' (unknown)

He (Father) is that tired of England, and as he (Father) lost his (Father) situation on the railway he (Father) has made up his (Father) mind to emigrate. It is pretty well all arranged; he (Father) has been to an agency and they say he (Father)'ll `ave to pay two pounds a `ead, and that runs to a lot of money in a big family like ours. So I'm likely to get left, for father says that I'm old enough to look after myself. He (father)'s willing to take me if I gets the money, not without. That's what I came to tell yer about.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther understood that Jenny had come to ask for money. She (Jenny) could not give it, and lapsed into thinking of this sudden loss of all her (Jenny) family. She (Jenny) did not know where Australia was; she (Jenny) fancied that she (Jenny) had once heard that it took months to get there. But she (Jenny) knew that they were all going from her (Jenny), they were going out on the sea in a great ship that would sail and sail further and further away. She (Jenny) could see the ship from her (Jenny) bedside, at first strangely distinct, alive with hands and handkerchiefs; she (Jenny) could distinguish all the children--Jenny, Julia, and little Ethel. She (Ethel) lost sight of their faces as the ship cleared the harbour. Soon after the ship was far away on the great round of waters, again a little while and all the streaming canvas not larger than a gull's wing, again a little while and the last speck on the horizon hesitated and disappeared.

``What are you crying about, Esther? I never saw yer cry before. It do seem that odd.'' (unknown)

``I'm so weak. Mother's death has broken my heart, and now to know that I shall never see any one of you again.'' (unknown)

``It do seem `ard. We shall miss you sadly. But I was going to say that father can't take me unless I finds two pounds. You won't see me stranded, will you, Esther?'' (unknown)

``I cannot give you the money, Jenny. Father has had too much of my money already; there's `ardly enough to see me through. I've only four pounds left. I cannot give you my child's money; God knows how we shall live until I can get to work again.'' (unknown)

``You're nearly well now. But if yer can't help me, yer can't. I don't know what's to be done. Father can't take me if I don't find the money.'' (unknown)

``You say the agency wants two pounds for each person?'' (unknown)

``Yes, that's it.'' (unknown)

``And I've four. We might both go if it weren't for the baby, but I don't suppose they'd make any charge for a child on the breast.'' (unknown)

``I dunno. There's father; yer know what he (father) is.'' (unknown)

``That's true. He (father) don't want me; I'm not one of his (father). But, Jenny, dear, it is terrible to be left all alone. Poor mother dead, and all of you going to Australia. I shall never see one of you again.'' (unknown)

The conversation paused. Esther changed the baby from the left to the right breast, and Jenny tried to think what she (Jenny) had best say to induce her (Jenny) sister to give her (Jenny) the money she (Jenny) wanted.

``If you don't give me the money I shall be left; it is hard luck, that's all, for there's fine chances for a girl, they says, out in Australia. If I remain `ere I dunno what will become of me.'' (unknown)

``You had better look out for a situation. We shall see each other from time to time. It's a pity you don't know a bit of cooking, enough to take the place of kitchen-maid.'' (unknown)

``I only know that dog-making, and I've `ad enough of that.'' (unknown)

``You know that I don't `old with all them preachy-preachy brethren says about the theatre.'' (unknown)

And then, as if prompted by some association of ideas, Esther said,
``I hope, Jenny, that you'll take example by me and will do nothing foolish; you'll always be a good girl.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

``Yes, if I gets the chance.'' (unknown)

``I'm sorry to `ear you speak like that, and poor mother only just dead.'' (Jenny)

The words that rose to Jenny's lips were:

``A nice one you are, with a baby at your breast, to come a-lecturing me,'' (Jenny)
but, fearing Esther's temper, she (Esther) checked the dangerous words and said instead--

``I didn't mean that I was a-going on the streets right away this very evening, only that a girl left alone in London without anyone to look to may go wrong in spite of herself, as it were.'' (she)

``A girl never need go wrong; if she (girl) does it is always `er own fault.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
Esther spoke mechanically, but suddenly remembering her (Esther) own circumstances she (Esther) said:
``I'd give you the money if I dared, but for the child's sake I mustn't.'' (she)

A few moments after Jenny returned with a good-looking, middle-aged woman. On her (Jenny) face there was that testy and perplexed look that comes of much business and many interruptions. Before she (Jenny) had opened her (Jenny) lips her (Jenny) face had said:

The matron examined in critical disdain the vague skirt, the broken boots, and the misshapen hat, coming all the while to rapid conclusions regarding the moral value of this unabashed child of the gutter.

``I think your sister will be very foolish if she (sister) gives you her (sister) money.'' (unknown)

said the matron.

``I didn't intend no impertinence,'' (Jenny)
said Jenny humbly,

``But,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Jenny and the matron turned suddenly and looked at the woman in the opposite bed who had so unexpectedly expressed her (Jenny) views. Jenny was furious.

``What odds is it to you?'' (she)

Esther was now alone in the world, and she (Esther) remembered the night she (Esther) walked home from the hospital and how cruel the city had seemed. She (Esther) was now alone in that great wilderness with her (Esther) child, for whom she (Esther) would have to work for many, many years. How would it all end? Would she (Esther) be able to live through it? Had she (Esther) done right in letting Jenny have the money--her (Jenny) boy's money? Her (woman) hair hung about her (woman), her (woman) hands and wrists were shrunken, her (woman) flesh was soft and flabby, and she (woman) had dark shadows in her (woman) face. ``Come, nurse, what is it? Come, the baby is waiting for you.'' (she)

A strange look passed over Mrs. Rivers' face. She (Rivers) knew, of course, that she (Rivers) stood well within the law, that she (Rivers) was doing no more than a hundred other fashionable women were doing at the same moment; but this plain girl had a plain way of putting things, and she (girl) did not care for it to be publicly known that the life of her (girl) child had been bought with the lives of two poor children. ``He (boy)'ll only be a drag on you. You'll never be able to bring him (boy) up, poor little bastard child.'' (unknown)

He (boy) is but a bastard, you say, and had better be dead and done with. I see it all now; I have been thinking it out. (the baby)

At that moment the baby began to cry; both women looked in the direction of the cradle.

``Nurse, you have utterly forgotten yourself, you have talked a great deal of nonsense, you have said a great deal that is untrue. The moment Esther got out of the house in Curzon Street she (Esther) felt in her (Esther) pocket for her (Esther) money. She (Esther) had only a few pence; enough for her (Esther) `bus fare, however, and her (Esther) thoughts did not go further. She (Esther) was absorbed by one desire, how to save her (Esther) child--how to save him (Esther) from Mrs. Spires, whom she (Spires) vaguely suspected; from the world, which called him (Esther) a bastard and denied to him (Esther) the right to live. The intensity and the oneness of her (woman) desire seemed to annihilate time, and when she (woman) got out of the omnibus she (woman) walked with a sort of animal-like instinct straight for the house. ``I'm all alone,'' (she)

``Not with that child yer won't--it ain't possible... You girls is all alike, yer thinks of nothing but yer babies for the first few weeks, then yer tires of them, the drag on yer is that `eavy--I knows yer--and then yer begins to wish they `ad never been born, or yer wishes they had died afore they knew they was alive. I don't say I'm not often sorry for them, poor little dears, but they takes less notice than you'd think for, and they is better out of the way; they really is, it saves a lot of trouble hereafter. I often do think that to neglect them, to let them go off quiet, that I be their best friend; not wilful neglect, yer know, but what is a woman to do with ten or a dozen, and I often `as as many? Esther did not answer, but judging by her (Esther) face that she (Esther) had lost all hope, Mrs. Spires was tempted to continue.

``There's that other baby in the far corner, that was brought `ere since you was `ere by a servant-girl like yerself. (unknown)

In truth, she (Spires) didn't know what to make of Esther. Was her (Esther) love of her (Esther) child such love as would enable her (Esther) to put up with all hardships for its sake, or was it the fleeting affection of the ordinary young mother, which, though ardent at first, gives way under difficulties? Mrs. Spires had heard many mothers talk as Esther talked, but when the real strain of life was put upon them they had yielded to the temptation of ridding themselves of their burdens. So Mrs. Spires could not believe that Esther was really different from the others, and if carefully handled she (Esther) would do what the others had done. Still, there was something in Esther which kept Mrs. Spires from making any distinct proposal. But it were a pity to let the girl slip through her (girl) fingers--five pounds were not picked up every day. There were three five-pound notes in the cradles. If Esther would listen to reason there would be twenty pounds, and the money was wanted badly. Once more greed set Mrs. Spires' tongue flowing, and, representing herself as a sort of guardian angel, she (Spires) spoke again about the mother of the dying child, pressing Esther to think what the girl's circumstances would have been if they had all lived.

``And they all died?'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther.

Just as Mrs. Spires was about to speak out she (Spires) noticed that Esther was in tears. Mrs. Spires always looked upon tears as a good sign, so she (Spires) resolved to give her (Spires) one more chance.
``What are you crying about?'' (she)

``Oh,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

She (Esther) would have to spend the night in the workhouse, and then?

She (Esther) did not know... All sorts of thoughts came upon her (Esther) unsolicited, and she (Esther) walked on and on. At last she (Esther) rested her (Esther) burden on the parapet of a bridge, and saw the London night, blue and gold, vast water rolling, and the spectacle of the stars like a dream from which she (Esther) could not disentangle her (Esther) individuality. Was she (Esther) to die in the star-lit city, she (Esther) and her (Esther) child; and why should such cruelty happen to her (Esther) more than to the next one? ``Why not go to the workhouse, only for the night?... She (babe) did not mind for herself, only she (babe) did not wish her (babe) boy to go there. But if God willed it...'' (she)

She (Esther) drew her (Esther) shawl about her (Esther) baby and tried once more to persuade herself into accepting the shelter of the workhouse. She (Esther) felt that if she (Esther) once entered the workhouse she (Esther) would remain there. She (Esther) and her (Esther) child paupers for ever.

``But what can I do?'' (she)
she (Esther) asked herself crazily, and sat down on one of the seats.

``No, sir; I'm out because I've no place to go.'' (unknown)

A full moon floated high up in the sky, and the city was no more than a faint shadow on the glassy stillness of the night; and she (Jones) longed to float away with the moon and the river, to be borne away out of sight of this world.

XX

Those who came to the workhouse for servants never offered more than fourteen pounds a year, and these wages would not pay for her (Jones) baby's keep out at nurse. Her (Jones) friend the matron did all she (Jones) could, but it was always fourteen pounds.

``We cannot afford more.'' (a tradesman)
At last an offer of sixteen pounds a year came from a tradesman in Chelsea; and the matron introduced Esther to Mrs. Lewis, a lonely widowed woman, who for five shillings a week would undertake to look after the child. This would leave Esther three pounds a year for dress; three pounds a year for herself.

What luck!

The shop was advantageously placed at a street corner. Twelve feet of fronting on the King's Road, and more than half that amount on the side street, exposed to every view wall papers and stained glass designs. The dwelling-house was over the shop; the shop entrance faced the kerb in the King's Road.

The Bingleys were Dissenters. They were ugly, and exacted the uttermost farthing from their customers and their workpeople. Mrs. Bingley was a tall, gaunt woman, with little grey ringlets on either side of her (Bingley) face. She (Bingley) spoke in a sour, resolute voice, when she (Bingley) came down in a wrapper to superintend the cooking. On Sundays she (Bingley) wore a black satin, fastened with a cameo brooch, and round her (Bingley) neck a long gold chain. Then her (Bingley) manners were lofty, and when her (Bingley) husband called

``Mother,'' (husband)
she (Bingley) answered testily,
``Don't keep on mothering me.'' (she)
She (Bingley) frequently stopped him (husband) to settle his (husband) necktie or collar. All the week he (husband) wore the same short jacket; on Sundays he (husband) appeared in an ill-fitting frock-coat. His (husband) long upper lip was clean shaven, but under his (husband) chin there grew a ring of discoloured hair, neither brown nor red, but the neutral tint that hair which does not turn grey acquires. When he (husband) spoke he (husband) opened his (husband) mouth wide, and seemed quite unashamed of the empty spaces and the three or four yellow fangs that remained.

John, the elder of the two brothers, was a silent youth whose one passion seemed to be eavesdropping. He (John) hung round doors in the hopes of overhearing his (John) sisters' conversation and if he (John) heard Esther and the little girl who helped Esther in her (Esther) work talking in the kitchen, he (John) would steal cautiously halfway down the stairs. Esther often thought that his (John) young woman must be sadly in want of a sweetheart to take on with one such as he (John).

``Come along, Amy,'' (he)
he (John) would cry, passing out before her (Esther); and not even at the end of a long walk did he (John) offer her (Esther) his (John) arm; and they came strolling home just like boy and girl.

Hubert, John's younger brother, was quite different. He (Hubert) had escaped the family temperament, as he (Hubert) had escaped the family upper lip. He (Hubert) was the one spot of colour in a somewhat sombre household, and Esther liked to hear him (Hubert) call back to his (Hubert) mother,

``All right, mother, I've got the key; no one need wait up for me. I'll make the door fast.'' (mother)

``Oh, Hubert, don't be later than eleven. You are not going out dancing again, are you? Your father will have the electric bell put on the door, so that he (father) may know when you come in.'' (The girls)

The four girls were all ruddy-complexioned and long upper-lipped. The eldest was the plainest; she (Esther) kept her (Esther) father's books, and made the pastry. The second and third entertained vague hopes of marriage. The youngest was subject to hysterics, fits of some kind.

The Bingleys' own house was representative of their ideas, and the taste they had imposed upon the neighbourhood. The staircase was covered with white drugget, and the white enamelled walls had to be kept scrupulously clean. There were no flowers in the windows, but the springs of the blinds were always in perfect order. The drawing-room was furnished with substantial tables, cabinets and chairs, and antimacassars, long and wide, and china ornaments and glass vases. There was a piano, and on this instrument, every Sunday evening, hymns were played by one of the young ladies, and the entire family sang in the chorus.

It was into this house that Esther entered as general servant, with wages fixed at sixteen pounds a year. And for seventeen long hours every day, for two hundred and thirty hours every fortnight, she (Esther) washed, she (Esther) scrubbed, she (Esther) cooked, she (Esther) ran errands, with never a moment that she (Esther) might call her (Esther) own. Every second Sunday she (Esther) was allowed out for four, perhaps for four and a half hours; the time fixed was from three to nine, but she (Esther) was expected to be back in time to get the supper ready, and if it were many minutes later than nine there were complaints.

She (Esther) had no money. Her (Esther) quarter's wages would not be due for another fortnight, and as they did not coincide with her (Esther) Sunday out, she (Esther) would not see her (Esther) baby for another three weeks. She (Esther) had not seen him (Esther) for a month, and a great longing was in her (Esther) heart to clasp him (Esther) in her (Esther) arms again, to feel his (Esther) soft cheek against hers, to take his (Esther) chubby legs and warm, fat feet in her (Esther) hands. XXI

It was the beginning of August, and London yawned in every street; the dust blew unslaked, and a little cloud curled and disappeared over the crest of the hill at Hyde Park Corner; the streets and St. George's Place looked out with blind, white eyes; and in the deserted Park the trees tossed their foliage restlessly, as if they wearied and missed the fashion of their season. And all through Park Lane and Mayfair, caretakers and gaunt cats were the traces that the caste on which Esther depended had left of its departed presence. She (Esther) was coming from the Alexandra Hotel, where she (Esther) had heard a kitchen-maid was wanted. Mrs. Lewis had urged her (Lewis) to wait until people began to come back to town. Good situations were rarely obtainable in the summer months; it would be bad policy to take a bad one, even if it were only for a while. Besides, she (Lewis) had saved a little money, and, feeling that she (Lewis) required a rest, had determined to take this advice. But as luck would have it Jackie fell ill before she (Jackie) had been at Dulwich a week. His (Lewis) illness made a big hole in her (Jackie) savings, and it had become evident that she (Jackie) would have to set to work and at once.

She (Jackie) turned into the park. She (Jackie) was going north, to a registry office near Oxford Street, which Mrs. Lewis had recommended. Holborn Row was difficult to find, and she (Lewis) had to ask the way very often, but she (Lewis) suddenly knew that she (Lewis) was in the right street by the number of servant-girls going and coming from the office, and in company with five others Esther ascended a gloomy little staircase. The office was on the first floor. The doors were open, and they passed into a special odour of poverty, as it were, into an atmosphere of mean interests.

Benches covered with red plush were on either side, and these were occupied by fifteen or twenty poorly-dressed women. A little old woman, very white and pale, stood near the window recounting her (woman) misfortunes to no one in particular.

The conversation paused. William spoke about the Barfields, and Esther could not but listen to the tale of what had happened at Woodview during the last eight years.

XXVIII

``I've `eard that argument. I know all about it, but it don't alter me. Too many strange things occur for me to think that everything can be calculated with a bit of lead-pencil in a greasy pocket-book.'' (unknown)

``What has the grease of my pocket-book to do with it?'' (Journeyman)
replied Journeyman, looking round. The company smiled and nodded.
``You says that signs and omens is above any calculation of weights. Never mind the pocket-book, greasy or not greasy; you says that these omens is more to be depended on than the best stable information.'' (unknown)

``I thought that you placed no reliance on stable information, and that you was guided by the weights that you calculated in that `ere pocket-book.'' (unknown)

``What's my pocket-book to do with it? You want to see my pocket-book; well, here it is, and I'll bet two glasses of beer that it ain't greasier than any other pocket-book in this bar.'' (unknown)

``I don't see meself what pocket-books, greasy or not greasy, has to do with it,'' (William/William Latch)
said William.
``Walter put a fair question to Herbert. The omen didn't come out right, and Walter wanted to know why it didn't come out right.'' (unknown)

``That was it,'' (Journeyman)
said Journeyman.

All eyes were now fixed on Ketley.

``You want to know why the omen wasn't right? I'll tell you--because it was no omen at all, that's why. The omens always comes right; it is we who aren't always in the particular state of mind that allows us to read the omens right.'' (Journeyman)
Journeyman shrugged his (Journeyman) shoulders contemptuously. Ketley looked at him (Journeyman) with the same expression of placid amusement.
``You'd like me to explain; well, I will. The omen is always right, but we aren't always in the state of mind for the reading of the omen. You think that ridiculous, Walter; but why should omens differ from other things? Some days we can get through our accounts in `alf the time we can at other times, the mind being clearer. I asks all present if that is not so.'' (Ketley/Mr. Ketley)

Ketley had got hold of his (Ketley) audience, and Journeyman's remark about closing time only provoked a momentary titter. Ketley looked long and steadily at Journeyman and then said,

``Perhaps closing time won't do no more for your calculation of weights than for my omens... I know them jokes, we've `eard them afore; but I'm not making jokes; I'm talking serious.'' (Journeyman)
The company nodded approval.
``I was saying there was times when the mind is fresh like the morning. That's the time for them what `as got the gift of reading the omens. It is a sudden light that comes into the mind, and it points straight like a ray of sunlight, if there be nothing to stop it... Now do you understand?'' (unknown)
No one had understood, but all felt that they were on the point of understanding.
``The whole thing is in there being nothing to interrupt the light.'' (unknown)

``But you says yourself that yer can't always read them,'' (Journeyman)
said Journeyman;
``an accident will send you off on the wrong tack, so it all comes to the same thing, omens or no omens.'' (Journeyman)

``A man will trip over a piece of wire laid across the street, but that don't prove he (man) can't walk, do it, Walter?'' (Walter)

Walter was unable to say that it did not, and so Ketley scored another point over his (Ketley) opponent.

``I made a mistake, I know I did, and if it will help you to understand I'll tell you how it was made. Three weeks ago I was in this `ere bar `aving what I usually takes. It was a bit early; none of you fellows had come in. I don't think it was much after eight. The governor was away in the north racin'--hadn't been `ome for three or four days; the missus was beginning to look a bit lonely.'' (Ketley/Mr. Ketley)
Ketley smiled and glanced at Esther, who had told Charles to serve some customers, and was listening as intently as the rest. ``I'd `ad a nice bit of supper, and was just feeling that fresh and clear `eaded as I was explaining to you just now is required for the reading, thinking of nothing in perticler, when suddenly the light came. I remembered a conversation I `ad with a chap about American corn. He (chap) wouldn't `ear of the Government taxing corn to `elp the British farmer. Well, that conversation came back to me as clear as if the dawn had begun to break. I could positively see the bloody corn; I could pretty well `ave counted it. I felt there was an omen about somewhere, and all of a tremble I took up the paper; it was lying on the bar just where your hand is, Walter. But at that moment, just as I was about to cast my eye down the list of `orses, a cab comes down the street as `ard as it could tear. There was but two or three of us in the bar, and we rushed out--the shafts was broke, `orse galloping and kicking, and the cabby `olding on as `ard as he (cabby) could. But it was no good, it was bound to go, and over it went against the kerb. The cabby, poor chap, was pretty well shook to pieces; his (chap) leg was broke, and we'd to `elp to take him (chap) to the hosspital. Now I asks if it was no more than might be expected that I should have gone wrong about the omen. Next day, as luck would have it, I rolled up `alf a pound of butter in a piece of paper on which
``Cross Roads' was written.'' (unknown)

``There's something in it,'' (a butcher)

Happiness flickered up through the old greyness of the face. Henceforth something to live for. Each morning bringing news of the horse, and the hours of the afternoon passing pleasantly, full of thoughts of the evening paper and the gossip of the bar. A bet on a race brings hope into lives which otherwise would be hopeless.

XXXI

Never had a Derby excited greater interest. Four hot favourites, between which the public seemed unable to choose. Two to one taken and offered against Fly-leaf, winner of the Two Thousand; four to one taken and offered against Signet-ring, who, half-trained, had run Fly-leaf to a head. Four to one against Necklace, the winner of the Middle Park Plate and the One Thousand. Seven to one against Dewberry, the brilliant winner of the Newmarket stakes. The chances of these horses were argued every night at the

``King's Head.'' (Ketley/Mr. Ketley)
Ketley's wife used to wear a string of yellow beads when she (wife) was a girl, but she (wife) wasn't certain what had become of them. Ketley did not wear a signet-ring, and had never known anyone who did. Dewberries grew on the river banks, but they were not ripe yet. Fly-leaf, he (Ketley) could not make much of that--not being much of a reader. So what with one thing and another Ketley didn't believe much in this `ere Derby. Journeyman caustically remarked that, omens or no omens, one horse was bound to win. Why didn't Herbert look for an omen among the outsiders? Old John's experiences led him (John) to think that the race lay between Fly-leaf and Signet-ring. He (John) had a great faith in blood, and Signet-ring came of a more staying stock than did Fly-leaf.
``When they begin to climb out of the dip Fly-leaf will have had about enough of it.'' (unknown)
Stack nodded approval. He (John) had five bob on Dewberry. He (Dewberry) didn't know much about his (Dewberry) staying powers, but all the stable is on him (Dewberry); ``and when I know the stable-money is right I says,
``That's good enough for me!''' (him)

Ginger, who came in occasionally, was very sweet on Necklace, whom he (Dewberry) declared to be the finest mare of the century. He (Dewberry) was listened to with awed attention, and there was a death-like silence in the bar when he (Dewberry) described how she (mare) had won the One Thousand. He (Dewberry) wouldn't have ridden her (mare) quite that way himself; but then what was a steeplechase rider's opinion worth regarding a flat race? The company demurred, and old John alluded to Ginger's magnificent riding when he (John) won the Liverpool on Foxcover, steadying the horse about sixty yards from home, and bringing him (John) up with a rush in the last dozen strides, nailing Jim Sutton, who had persevered all the way, on the very post by a head. Bill Evans, who happened to look in that evening, said that he (Evans) would not be surprised to see all the four favourites bowled out by an outsider. He (Evans) had heard something that was good enough for him (Evans). He (Evans) didn't suppose the guv`nor would take him (Evans) on the nod, but he (Evans) had a nice watch which ought to be good for three ten.

``Turn it up, old mate,'' (William/William Latch)
said William.

I'm a bit short of money, and have a fancy for a certain outsider. I'd like to have my bit on, and I'll dispose of the ticket for--what do you say to a thin `un, Mr. Ketley?'' (unknown)

``Did you `ear me speak just now?'' (William/William Latch)

``William Latch, London,'' (unknown)
in gold letters on a green ground--was laid on top. The boots with soles three inches high went into the box on which William stood while he (William) halloaed his (William) prices to the crowd. Then there were the two poles which supported a strip of white linen, on which was written in gold letters, ``William Latch, ``The King's Head,
'' London. Fair prices, prompt payment.'' (The King)

It was a grey day, with shafts of sunlight coming through, and as the cab passed over Waterloo Bridge, London, various embankments and St. Paul's on one side, wharves and warehouses on the other, appeared in grey curves and straight silhouettes. The pavements were lined with young men--here and there a girl's dress was a spot of colour in the grey morning. At the station they met Journeyman and old John, but Sarah was nowhere to be found. William said--

``We shall be late; we shall have to go without her (They).'' (William/William Latch)

Esther's face clouded.

``We can't go without her (They); don't be so impatient.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
At that moment a white muslin was seen in the distance, and Esther said,
``I think that that's Sarah.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

``You can chatter in the train--you'll have a whole hour to talk about each other's dress; get in, get in,'' (William/William Latch)
and William pressed them into a third-class carriage. They had not seen each other for so long a while, and there was so much to say that they did not know where to begin. Sarah was the first to speak.

``It was kind of you to think of me. So you've married, and to him (King) after all!'' (she)
she (Sarah) added, lowering her (Sarah) voice.

Esther laughed.

``It do seem strange, don't it?'' (unknown)

``You'll tell me all about it,'' (she)
she (Esther) said.
``I wonder we didn't run across one another before.'' (unknown)

They rolled out of the grey station into the light, and the plate-glass drew the rays together till they burnt the face and hands. They sped alongside of the upper windows nearly on a level with the red and yellow chimney-pots; they passed open spaces filled with cranes, old iron, and stacks of railway sleepers, pictorial advertisements, sky signs, great gasometers rising round and black in their iron cages over-topping or nearly the slender spires. A train steamed along a hundred-arched viaduct; and along a black embankment the other trains rushed by in a whirl of wheels, bringing thousands of clerks up from the suburbs to their city toil.

The excursion jogged on, stopping for long intervals before strips of sordid garden where shirts and pink petticoats were blowing. Little streets ascended the hillsides; no more trams, `buses, too, had disappeared, and afoot the folk hurried along the lonely pavements of their suburbs. At Clapham Junction betting men had crowded the platform; they all wore grey overcoats with race-glasses slung over their shoulders. And the train still rolled through the brick wilderness which old John said was all country forty years ago.

The men puffed at their pipes, and old John's anecdotes about the days when he (John) and the Gaffer, in company with all the great racing men of the day, used to drive down by road, were listened to with admiration. Esther had finished telling the circumstances in which she (Esther) had met Margaret; and Sarah questioned her (Sarah) about William and how her (Sarah) marriage had come about. The train had stopped outside of a little station, and the blue sky, with its light wispy clouds, became a topic of conversation. Old John did not like the look of those clouds, and the women glanced at the waterproofs which they carried on their arms.

They passed bits of common with cows and a stray horse, also a little rural cemetery; but London suddenly began again parish after parish, the same blue roofs, the same tenement houses. The train had passed the first cedar and the first tennis lawn. And knowing it to be a Derby excursion the players paused in their play and looked up. Again the line was blocked; the train stopped again and again. But it had left London behind, and the last stoppage was in front of a beautiful June landscape. A thick meadow with a square weather-beaten church showing between the spreading trees; miles of green corn, with birds flying in the bright air, and lazy clouds going out, making way for the endless blue of a long summer's day.

XXXII

It had been arranged that William should don his (William) betting toggery at the

``Spread Eagle Inn.'' (William/William Latch)
It stood at the cross-roads, only a little way from the station--a square house with a pillared porch. Even at this early hour the London pilgrimage was filing by. Horses were drinking in the trough; their drivers were drinking in the bar; girls in light dresses shared glasses of beer with young men. But the greater number of vehicles passed without stopping, anxious to get on the course. They went round the turn in long procession, a policeman on a strong horse occupied the middle of the road. The waggonettes and coaches had red-coated guards, and the air was rent with the tooting of the long brass horns. Every kind of dingy trap went by, sometimes drawn by two, sometimes by only one horse--shays half a century old jingled along; there were even donkey-carts. Esther and Sarah were astonished at the number of costers, but old John told them that that was nothing to what it was fifty years ago. The year that Andover won the block began seven or eight miles from Epsom. They were often half-an-hour without moving. Such chaffing and laughing, the coster cracked his (John) joke with the duke, but all that was done away with now.

``Gracious!'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther, when William appeared in his (William) betting toggery.
``I shouldn't have known you.'' (He)

He (William) did seem very wonderful in his (William) checks, green necktie, yellow flowers, and white hat with its gold inscription,

``Mr. William Latch, London.'' (He)

``It's all right,'' (he)
he (William) said;
``you never saw me before in these togs--fine, ain't they? But we're very late. Mr. North has offered to run me up to the course, but he (Mr.)'s only two places. Teddy and me must be getting along--but you needn't hurry. The races won't begin for hours yet. It's only about a mile--a nice walk. These gentlemen will look after you. You know where to find me,'' (he)
he (William) said, turning to John and Walter.
``You'll look after my wife and Miss Tucker, won't you?'' (he)

said Sarah.

said Journeyman.

Recollections of what the road had once been had loosened John's tongue, and he (John) continued his (John) reminiscences of the great days when Sir Thomas Hayward had laid fifteen thousand to ten thousand three times over against the favourite. The third bet had been laid at this very spot, but the Duke would not accept the third bet, saying that the horse was then being backed on the course at evens. So Sir Thomas had only lost thirty thousand pounds on the race. Journeyman was deeply interested in the anecdote; but Sarah looked at the old man with a look that said,

``Well, if I'm to pass the day with you two I never want to go to the Derby again... Come on in front,'' (the man)
she (Sarah) whispered to Esther,
``and let them talk about their racing by themselves.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
The way led through a field ablaze with buttercups; it passed by a fish-pond into which three drunkards were gazing.
``Do you hear what they're saying about the fish?'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah.

``Don't pay no attention to them,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther.
``If you knew as much about drunkards as I do, you'd want no telling to give them a wide berth... Isn't the country lovely? Isn't the air soft and warm?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't want no more country. I'm that glad to get back to town. I wouldn't take another situation out of London if I was offered twenty a year.'' (unknown)

``But look,'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
said Esther,
``at the trees. I've hardly been in the country since I left Woodview, unless you call Dulwich the country--that's where Jackie was at nurse.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

The Cockney pilgrimage passed into a pleasant lane overhung with chestnut and laburnum trees. The spring had been late, and the white blossoms stood up like candles--the yellow dropped like tassels, and the streaming sunlight filled the leaves with tints of pale gold, and their light shadows patterned the red earth of the pathway. But very soon this pleasant pathway debouched on a thirsting roadway where tired horses harnessed to heavy vehicles toiled up a long hill leading to the Downs. The trees intercepted the view, and the blown dust whitened the foliage and the wayside grass, now in possession of hawker and vagrant. The crowd made way for the traps; and the young men in blue and grey trousers, and their girls in white dresses, turned and watched the four horses bringing along the tall drag crowned with London fashion. There the unwieldly omnibus and the brake filled with fat girls in pink dresses and yellow hats, and there the spring cart drawn up under a hedge. The cottage gates were crowded with folk come to see London going to the Derby. Outhouses had been converted into refreshment bars, and from these came a smell of beer and oranges; further on there was a lamentable harmonium--a blind man singing hymns to its accompaniment, and a one-legged man holding his (man) hat for alms; and not far away there stood an earnest-eyed woman offering tracts, warning folk of their danger, beseeching them to retrace their steps.

At last the trees ceased and they found themselves on the hilltop in a glare of sunlight, on a space of worn ground where donkeys were tethered.

``Is this the Derby?'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah.

``I hope you're not disappointed?'' (unknown)

``No, dear; but where's all the people--the drags, the carriages?'' (unknown)

``We'll see them presently,'' (John/John Waters)
said old John, and he (John) volunteered some explanations. The white building was the Grand Stand. The winning-post was a little further this way.

``Where do they start?'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah.

``Over yonder, where you see that clump. They run through the furze right up to Tattenham Corner.'' (the women)

A vast crowd swarmed over the opposite hill, and beyond the crowd the women saw a piece of open downland dotted with bushes, and rising in gentle incline to a belt of trees which closed the horizon.

``Where them trees are, that's _Tattenham Corner_.'' (John/John Waters)
The words seemed to fill old John with enthusiasm, and he (John) described how the horses came round this side of the trees.
``They comes right down that `ere `ill--there's the dip--and they finishes opposite to where we is standing. Yonder, by Barnard's Ring.'' (unknown)

said Sarah.

What had attracted Sarah's attention was a boy walking through the crowd on a pair of stilts fully eight feet high. He (boy) uttered short warning cries from time to time, held out his (boy) wide trousers and caught pennies in his (boy) conical cap. Drags and carriages continued to arrive. The sweating horses were unyoked, and grooms and helpers rolled the vehicles into position along the rails. Lackeys drew forth cases of wine and provisions, and the flutter of table-cloths had begun to attract vagrants, itinerant musicians, fortune-tellers, begging children. All these plied their trades round the fashion of grey frock-coats and silk sun-shades. Along the rails rough fellows lay asleep; the place looked like a vast dormitory; they lay with their hats over their faces, clay pipes sticking from under the brims, their brown-red hands upon the grey grass.

Suddenly old John pleaded an appointment; he (John) was to meet a friend who would give him (John) the very latest news respecting a certain horse; and Esther, Sarah, and Journeyman wandered along the course in search of William. Along the rails strangely-dressed men stood on stools, satchels and race-glasses slung over their shoulders, great bouquets in their button-holes. Each stood between two poles on which was stretched a piece of white-coloured linen, on which was inscribed their name in large gold letters. Sarah read some of these names out:

``Jack Hooper, Marylebone. All bets paid.'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
``Tom Wood's famous boxing rooms, Epsom.'' (unknown)
``James Webster, Commission Agent, London.'' (these men)
And these betting men bawled the prices from the top of their high stools and shook their satchels, which were filled with money, to attract custom.
``What can I do for you to-day, sir?'' (any man)
they shouted when they caught the eye of any respectably-dressed man.
``On the Der-by, on the Der-by, I'll bet the Der-by... To win or a place, to win or a place, to win or a place--seven to one bar two or three, seven to one bar two or three... the old firm, the old firm,'' (unknown)
--like so many challenging cocks, each trying to outshrill the other.

Under the hill-side in a quiet hollow had been pitched a large and commodious tent. Journeyman mentioned that it was the West London Gospel-tent. He (Journeyman) thought the parson would have it pretty well all to himself, and they stopped before a van filled with barrels of Watford ales. A barrel had been taken from the van and placed on a small table; glasses of beer were being served to a thirsty crowd; and all around were little canvas shelters, whence men shouted,

''`Commodation, `commodation.'' (whence men)

The sun had risen high, and what clouds remained floated away like filaments of white cotton. The Grand Stand, dotted like a ceiling with flies, stood out distinct and harsh upon a burning plain of blue. The light beat fiercely upon the booths, the carriages, the vehicles, the

``rings,'' (unknown)
the various stands. The country around was lost in the haze and dazzle of the sunlight; but a square mile of downland fluttered with flags and canvas, and the great mob swelled, and smoked, and drank, shied sticks at Aunt Sally, and rode wooden horses. And through this crush of perspiring, shrieking humanity Journeyman, Esther, and Sarah sought vainly for William. The form of the ground was lost in the multitude and they could only tell by the strain in their limbs whether they were walking up or down hill. Sarah declared herself to be done up, and it was with difficulty that she (Sarah) was persuaded to persevere a little longer. At last Journeyman caught sight of the bookmaker's square shoulders.

After luncheon Journeyman, who was making no way with Sarah, took his (Journeyman) leave, pleading that he (Journeyman) had some friends to meet in Barnard's Ring. He (husband) shouted the odds, willing to bet against every horse, distributed tickets to the various folk that crowded round him (husband), each with his (husband) preference, his (husband) prejudice, his (husband) belief in omens, in tips, or in the talent and luck of a favourite jockey. Sarah continued her (Sarah) cursive chatter regarding the places she (Sarah) had served in. She (Sarah) felt inclined for a snooze, but was afraid it would not look well. While hesitating she (Sarah) ceased speaking, and both women fell asleep under the shade of their parasols. It was the shallow, glassy sleep of the open air, through which they divined easily the great blur that was the race-course.

They could hear William's voice, and they heard a bell ring and shouts of

``Here they come!'' (William/William Latch)

``It's all very well for you,'' (she)
she (Sarah) said.

They were two nice-looking English women of the lower classes, prettily dressed in light gowns with cheap sunshades in their cotton-gloved hands. Sarah looked at every young man with regretful eyes. ``King's Head,'' (he)

She (Esther) walked by Sarah's side, quite ignored, until she (Sarah) was accosted by Fred Parsons. They were passing by the mission tent, and Fred was calling upon the folk to leave the ways of Satan for those of Christ. Bill Evans was about to answer some brutal insult; but seeing that

XXXIII

The crowd shouted. She (Esther) looked where the others looked, but saw only the burning blue with the white stand marked upon it. It was crowded like the deck of a sinking vessel, and Esther wondered at the excitement, the cause of which was hidden from her (Esther). She (Esther) wandered to the edge of the crowd until she (Esther) came to a chalk road where horses and mules were tethered. A little higher up she (Esther) entered the crowd again, and came suddenly upon a switchback railway. Full of laughing and screaming girls, it bumped over a middle hill, and then rose slowly till it reached the last summit. It was shot back again into the midst of its fictitious perils, and this mock voyaging was accomplished to the sound of music from a puppet orchestra. Bells and drums, a fife and a triangle, cymbals clashed mechanically, and a little soldier beat the time. Further on, under a striped awning, were the wooden horses. They were arranged so well that they rocked to and fro, imitating as nearly as possible the action of real horses. Esther watched the riders. A blue skirt looked like a riding habit, and a girl in salmon pink leaned back in her (girl) saddle just as if she (girl) had been taught how to ride. A girl in a grey jacket encouraged a girl in white who rode a grey horse. But before Esther could make out for certain that the man in the blue Melton jacket was Bill Evans he (Evans) had passed out of sight, and she (Esther) had to wait until his (Evans) horse came round the second time. At that moment she (Esther) caught sight of the red poppies in Sarah's hat.

The horses began to slacken speed. They went slower and slower, then stopped altogether. The riders began to dismount and Esther pressed through the bystanders, fearing she (Esther) would not be able to overtake her (Esther) friends.

``Oh, here you are,'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah.
``I thought I never should find you again. How hot it is!'' (unknown)

``Were you on in that ride? Let's have another, all three of us. These three horses.'' (unknown)

Round and round they went, their steeds bobbing nobly up and down to the sound of fifes, drums and cymbals. They passed the winning-post many times; they had to pass it five times, and the horse that stopped nearest it won the prize. A long-drawn-out murmur, continuous as the sea, swelled up from the course--a murmur which at last passed into words:

``Here they come; blue wins, the favourite's beat.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
Esther paid little attention to these cries; she (Esther) did not understand them; they reached her (Esther) indistinctly and soon died away, absorbed in the strident music that accompanied the circling horses. These had now begun to slacken speed... They went slower and slower. Sarah and Bill, who rode side by side, seemed like winning, but at the last moment they glided by the winning-post. Esther's steed stopped in time, and she (Esther) was told to choose a china mug from a great heap.

``You've all the luck to-day,'' (Bill/Bill Evans/Evans)
said Bill.
``Hayfield, who was backed all the winter, broke down a month ago... 2 to 1 against Fly-leaf, 4 to 1 against Signet-ring, 4 to 1 against Dewberry, 10 to 1 against Vanguard, the winner at 50 to 1 offered. Your husband must have won a little fortune. Never was there such a day for the bookies.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

Esther said she (Esther) was very glad, and was undecided which mug she (Esther) should choose. At last she (Esther) saw one on which

``Jack'' (she)
was written in gold letters. They then visited the peep-shows, and especially liked St. James's Park with the Horse Guards out on parade; the Spanish bull-fight did not stir them, and Sarah couldn't find a single young man to her (Sarah) taste in the House of Commons. Among the performing birds they liked best a canary that climbed a ladder. Bill was attracted by the American strength-testers, and he (Bill) gave an exhibition of his (Bill) muscle, to Sarah's very great admiration. They all had some shies at cocoa-nuts, and passed by J. Bilton's great bowling saloon without visiting it. Once more the air was rent with the cries of
``Here they come! Here they come!'' (the commodation men)
Even the `commodation men left their canvas shelters and pressed forward inquiring which had won. A moment after a score of pigeons floated and flew through the blue air and then departed in different directions, some making straight for London, others for the blue mysterious evening that had risen about the Downs--the sun-baked Downs strewn with waste paper and covered by tipsy men and women, a screaming and disordered animality.

``Well, so you've come back at last,'' (William/William Latch)
said William.
``The favourite was beaten. I suppose you know that a rank outsider won. But what about this gentleman?'' (unknown)

``Met these `ere ladies on the `ill an' been showing them over the course. No offence, I hope, guv`nor?'' (William/William Latch)

William did not answer, and Bill took leave of Sarah in a manner that told Esther that they had arranged to meet again.

``Where did you pick up that bloke?'' (unknown)

``He (bloke) came up and spoke to us, and Esther stopped to speak to the parson.'' (unknown)

``To the parson. What do you mean?'' (William/William Latch)

The circumstance was explained, and William asked them what they thought of the racing.

``We didn't see no racing,'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah;
``we was on the `ill on the wooden `orses. Esther's `orse won. She (Esther) got a mug; show the mug, Esther.'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)

``So you saw no Derby after all?'' (William/William Latch)
said William.

``Saw no racin'!'' (neighbour)
said his (William) neighbour;
``ain't she (Esther) won the cup?'' (neighbour)

The joke was lost on the women, who only perceived that they were being laughed at.

``Come up here, Esther,'' (William/William Latch)
said William;
``stand on my box. The `orses are just going up the course for the preliminary canter. And you, Sarah, take Teddy's place. Teddy, get down, and let the lady up.'' (William/William Latch)

``Yes, guv`nor. Come up `ere, ma'am.'' (unknown)

``And is those the `orses?'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah.
``They do seem small.'' (unknown)

The ringmen roared.

``Not up to those on the `ill, ma'am,'' (unknown)
said one.
``Not such beautiful goers,'' (unknown)
said another.

There were two or three false starts, and then, looking through a multitude of hats, Esther saw five or six thin greyhound-looking horses. They passed like shadows, flitted by; and she (Esther) was sorry for the poor chestnut that trotted in among the crowd.

This was the last race. Once more the favourite had been beaten; there were no bets to pay, and the bookmakers began to prepare for departure. It was the poor little clerks who were charged with the luggage. Teddy did not seem as if he (Teddy) would ever reach the top of the hill. With Esther and Sarah on either arm, William struggled with the crowd. It was hard to get through the block of carriages. Everywhere horses waited with their harness on, and Sarah was afraid of being bitten or kicked. A young aristocrat cursed them from the box-seat, and the groom blew a blast as the drag rolled away. It was like the instinct of departure which takes a vast herd at a certain moment. The great landscape, half country, half suburb, glinted beneath the rays of a setting sun; and through the white dust, and the drought of the warm roads, the brakes and carriages and every crazy vehicle rolled towards London; orange-sellers, tract-sellers, thieves, vagrants, gipsies, made for their various quarters--roadside inns, outhouses, hayricks, hedges, or the railway station. Down the long hill the vast crowd made its way, humble pedestrians and carriage folk, all together, as far as the cross-roads. At the

``Spread Eagle'' (stoppage the bookmakers)
there would be stoppage for a parting drink, there the bookmakers would change their clothes, and there division would happen in the crowd--half for the railway station, half for the London road. It was there that the traditional sports of the road began. A drag, with a band of exquisites armed with pea-shooters, peppering on costers who were getting angry, and threatening to drive over the leaders. A brake with two poles erected, and hanging on a string quite a line of miniature chamber-pots. A horse, with his (bookmakers) fore-legs clothed in a pair of lady's drawers. Naturally unconscious of the garment, the horse stepped along so absurdly that Esther and Sarah thought they'd choke with laughter.

At the station William halloaed to old John, whom he (John) caught sight of on the platform. He (John) had backed the winner--forty to one about Sultan. It was Ketley who had persuaded him (Ketley) to risk half a sovereign on the horse. Ketley was at the Derby; he (Ketley) had met him (Ketley) on the course, and Ketley had told him (Ketley) a wonderful story about a packet of Turkish Delight. The omen had come right this time, and Journeyman took a back seat.

``Say what you like,'' (William/William Latch)
said William,
``it is damned strange; and if anyone did find the way of reading them omens there would be an end of us bookmakers.'' (William/William Latch)
He (William) was only half in earnest, but he (William) regretted he (William) had not met Ketley. If he (William) had only had a fiver on the horse--200 to 5!

They met Ketley at Waterloo, and every one wanted to hear from his (Ketley) own lips the story of the packet of Turkish Delight. So William proposed they should all come up to the

``King's Head'' (William/William Latch)

``Which is the best dinner here?'' (he)

William had ordered champagne, but it had not proved to any one's taste except, perhaps, to Sarah, whom it rendered unduly hilarious; nor did the delicate food afford much satisfaction; the servants played with it, and left it on their plates; and it was not until William ordered up the saddle of mutton and carved it himself that the dinner began to take hold of the company. Esther and Sarah enjoyed the ices, and the men stuck to the cheese, a fine Stilton, which was much appreciated. Coffee no one cared for, and the little glasses of brandy only served to augment the general tipsiness. William said,

``Now let's `ear the blo--the bloody omen that put ye on to Sultan--that blood--packet of Turkish Delight.'' (William/William Latch)

But the company was none the less pleased with it, and willingly declared that bookmaking was only a game for mugs. Get on a winner at forty to one, and you could make as much in one bet as a poor devil of a bookie could in six months, fagging from race-course to race-course. They drank, argued, and quarrelled, until Esther noticed that Sarah was looking very pale. They stood on the pavement's edge, a little puzzled by the brilliancy of the moonlight. And the three men who followed out of the bar-room were agreed regarding the worthlessness of life. One said,

``I don't think much of it; all I live for is beer and women.'' (William/William Latch)

XXXIV

Things went well enough as long as her (Sarah) savings lasted. When her (Sarah) money was gone Bill returned to the race-course in the hope of doing a bit of welshing. Soon after he (Bill) was

``wanted'' (he)
by the police; they escaped to Belgium, and it devolved on Sarah to support him (Bill). The hue and cry over, they came back to London.

She (Sarah) had been sitting up for him (Bill); he (Bill) had come home exasperated and disappointed. A row soon began; and she (Sarah) thought that he (Bill) would strike her (Sarah). But he (Bill) refrained, for fear, perhaps, of the other lodgers. He (Bill) took her (Sarah) instead by the arm, dragged her (Sarah) down the broken staircase, and pushed her (Sarah) into the court. She (Sarah) heard the retreating footsteps, and saw a cat slink through a grating, and she (Sarah) wished that she (Sarah) too could escape from the light into the dark.

A few belated women still lingered in the Strand, and the city stood up like a prison, hard and stark in the cold, penetrating light of morning. She (Sarah) sat upon a pillar's base, her (Sarah) eyes turned towards the cabmen's shelter. The horses munched in their nose-bags, and the pigeons came down from their roosts. She (Sarah) was dressed in an old black dress, her (Sarah) hands lay upon her (Sarah) knees, and the pose expressed so perfectly the despair and wretchedness in her (Sarah) soul that a young man in evening clothes, who had looked sharply at her (Sarah) as he (man) passed, turned and came back to her (Sarah), and he (man) asked her (Sarah) if he (man) could assist her (Sarah). She (Sarah) answered,

``Thank you, sir.'' (She)

The disordered red hair, the thin, freckled face, were expressive, and so too was the movement of her (Sarah) body when she (Sarah) got up and walked, not knowing and not caring where she (Sarah) was going. There was sensation of the river in her (Sarah) thoughts; the river drew her (Sarah), and she (Sarah) indistinctly remembered that she (Sarah) would find relief there if she (Sarah) chose to accept that relief. The water was blue beneath the sunrise, and it seemed to offer to end her (Sarah) life's trouble. She (Sarah) could not go on living. She (Sarah) could not bear with her (Sarah) life any longer, and yet she (Sarah) knew that she (Sarah) would not drown herself that morning. There was not enough will in her (Sarah) to drown herself. She (Sarah) was merely half dead with grief. He (Sarah) had turned her (Sarah) out, he (Sarah) had said that he (Sarah) never wanted to see her (Sarah) again, but that was because he (Sarah) had been unlucky. She (Sarah) ought to have gone to bed and not waited up for him (Sarah); he (Sarah) didn't know what he (Sarah) was doing; so long as he (Sarah) didn't care for another woman there was hope that he (Sarah) might come back to her (woman). The spare trees rustled their leaves in the bright dawn air, and she (woman) sat down on a bench and watched the lamps going out, and the river changing from blue to brown. Hours passed, and the same thoughts came and went, until with sheer weariness of thinking she (woman) fell asleep.

She (woman) was awakened by the policeman, and she (woman) once more continued her (woman) walk. The omnibuses had begun; women were coming from market with baskets on their arms; and she (woman) wondered if their lovers and husbands were unfaithful to them, if they would be received with blows or knocks when they returned. Her (woman) slightest mistakes had often, it seemed, merited a blow; and God knows she (woman) had striven to pick out the piece of bacon that she (woman) thought he (God) would like, and it was not her (woman) fault that she (woman) couldn't get any money nowhere. Why was he (God) cruel to her (woman)? He (God) never would find another woman to care for him (God) more than she (woman) did... Esther had a good husband, Esther had always been lucky. Two hours more to wait, and she (Esther) felt so tired, so tired. The milk-women were calling their ware--those lusty short-skirted women that bring an air of country into the meanest alley. She (Esther) sat down on a doorstep and looked on the empty Haymarket, vaguely conscious of the low vice which still lingered there though the morning was advancing. She (Esther) turned up Shaftesbury Avenue, and from the beginning of Dean Street she (Esther) watched to see if the shutters were yet down. The sun was shining, and she (Esther) watched the cab horses, until the potboy came through and began cleaning the street lamp. XXXV

Lacking a parlour on the ground floor for the use of special customers, William had arranged a room upstairs where they could smoke and drink. There were tables in front of the windows and chairs against the walls, and in the middle of the room a bagatelle board.

When William left off going to race-courses he (William) had intended to refrain from taking money across the bar and to do all his (William) betting business in this room.

He (William) thought that it would be safer. But as his (William) customers multiplied he (William) found that he (William) could not ask them all upstairs; it attracted more attention than to take the money quietly across the bar. Nevertheless the room upstairs had proved a success. A man spent more money if he (man) had a room where he (man) could sit quietly among his (man) friends than he (man) would seated on a high stool in a public bar, jostled and pushed about; so it had come to be considered a sort of club room; and a large part of the neighbourhood came there to read the papers, to hear and discuss the news. And specially useful it had proved to Journeyman and Stack. Neither was now in employment; they were now professional backers; and from daylight to dark they wandered from public-house to public-house, from tobacconist to barber's shop, in the search of tips, on the quest of stable information regarding the health of the horses and their trials. But the room upstairs at the

``King's Head'' (unknown)
was the centre of their operations. Stack was the indefatigable tipster, Journeyman was the scientific student of public form. His (Journeyman) memory was prodigious, and it enabled him (Journeyman) to note an advantage in the weights which would escape an ordinary observer. He (Journeyman) often picked out horses which, if they did not actually win, nearly always stood at a short price in the betting before the race.

The

``King's Head'' (unknown)
was crowded during the dinner-hour. Barbers and their assistants, cabmen, scene-shifters, if there was an afternoon performance at the theatre, servants out of situation and servants escaped from their service for an hour, petty shopkeepers, the many who grow weary of the scant livelihood that work brings them, came there. Eleven o'clock! In another hour the bar and the room upstairs would be crowded. At present the room was empty, and Journeyman had taken advantage of the quiet time to do a bit of work at his (Journeyman) handicap. All the racing of the last three years lay within his (Journeyman) mind's range; he (Journeyman) recalled at will every trifling selling race; hardly ever was he (Journeyman) obliged to refer to the Racing Calendar. Wanderer had beaten Brick at ten pounds. Snow Queen had beaten Shoemaker at four pounds, and Shoemaker had beaten Wanderer at seven pounds. The problem was further complicated by the suspicion that Brick could get a distance of ground better than Snow Queen. Journeyman was undecided. He (Journeyman) stroked his (Journeyman) short brown moustache with his (Journeyman) thin, hairy hand, and gnawed the end of his (Journeyman) pen. XXXVI

One afternoon Fred Parsons came into the bar of the

``King's Head.'' (Fred/Fred Parsons/Parsons)

Esther and the potboy were alone in the house. The potman was at work in the backyard, Esther was sewing in the parlour. Hearing steps, she (Esther) went into the bar. XXXVII

On Sunday, as soon as dinner was over, Esther had intended to go to East Dulwich to see Mrs. Lewis. But as she (Lewis) closed the door behind her (Lewis), she (Lewis) saw Sarah coming up the street.

``Ah, I see you're going out.'' (unknown)

``It don't matter; won't you come in, if it's only for a minute?'' (unknown)

They walked down Waterloo Place and along Pall Mall. In Trafalgar Square there was a demonstration, and Sarah lingered in the crowd so long that when they arrived at Charing Cross, Esther found that she (Esther) could not get to Ludgate Hill in time to catch her (Esther) train, so they went into the Embankment Gardens. It had been raining, and the women wiped the seats with their handkerchiefs before sitting down. Sarah's chatter was equally irrelevant, and Esther wondered how Sarah could talk so much about nothing, and regretted her (Sarah) visit to East Dulwich more and more. ``But I thought you didn't see him (fellow) any more; you promised us you wouldn't.'' (unknown)

``He (fellow) said,

The courts and alleys had vomited their population into the Lane. Fat girls clad in shawls sat around the slum opening nursing their babies.
