This was the block in which Sarah had lived. A space had been cleared by the builder, and the other side was shut in by the great wall of the old theatre.

``That's where we used to live,'' (Sarah/Sarah Tucker)
said Sarah, pointing up to the third floor.

XL

The magistrate of course sent the case for trial, and the thirty pounds which William had promised to give to Esther went to pay for the defence. There seemed at first some hope that the prosecution would not be able to prove its case, but fresh evidence connecting Sarah with the abstraction of the plate was forthcoming, and in the end it was thought advisable that the plea of not guilty should be withdrawn. The efforts of counsel were therefore directed towards a mitigation of sentence. Counsel called Esther and William for the purpose of proving the excellent character that the prisoner had hitherto borne; counsel spoke of the evil influence into which the prisoner had fallen, and urged that she (Esther) had no intention of actually stealing the plate. Tempted by promises, she (Esther) had been persuaded to pledge the plate in order to back a horse which she (Esther) had been told was certain to win. If that horse had won, the plate would have been redeemed and returned to its proper place in the owner's house, and the prisoner would have been able to marry. Possibly the marriage on which the prisoner had set her (Esther) heart would have turned out more unfortunate for the prisoner than the present proceedings. Counsel had not words strong enough to stigmatise the character of a man who, having induced a girl to imperil her (girl) liberty for his (Counsel) own vile ends, was cowardly enough to abandon her (girl) in the hour of her (girl) deepest distress. Counsel drew attention to the trusting nature of the prisoner, who had not only pledged her (girl) employer's plate at his (Counsel) base instigation, but had likewise been foolish enough to confide the pawn-ticket to his (Counsel) keeping. Such was the prisoner's story, and he (Counsel) submitted that it bore on the face of it the stamp of truth. A very sad story, but one full of simple, foolish, trusting humanity, and, having regard to the excellent character the prisoner had borne, counsel hoped that his (prisoner) lordship would see his (prisoner) way to dealing leniently with her (girl).

His (prisoner) Lordship, whose gallantries had been prolonged over half a century, and whose betting transactions were matters of public comment, pursed up his (prisoner) ancient lips and fixed his (prisoner) dead glassy eyes on the prisoner. He (prisoner) said he (prisoner) regretted that he (prisoner) could not take the same view of the prisoner's character as learned counsel had done. The police had made every effort to apprehend the man Evans who, according to the prisoner's story, was the principal culprit. They were in for a humorous speech, and the prisoner would get off with a light sentence. But the grim smile waxed duller, and it was clear that lordship was determined to make the law a terror to evil-doers. Lordship drew attention to the fact that during the course of their investigations the police had discovered that the prisoner had been living for some considerable time with the man Evans, during which time several robberies had been effected. There was no evidence, it was true, to connect the prisoner with these robberies. The prisoner had left the man Evans and had obtained a situation in the house of her (police) present employers. When the characters she (police) had received from her (police) former employers were being examined she (police) had accounted for the year she (police) had spent with the man Evans by saying that she (police) had been staying with the Latches, the publicans who had given evidence in her (police) favour. ``King's Head,'' (Bill/Bill Evans/Evans)

Here lordship indulged in severe remarks against those who enabled not wholly irreproachable characters to obtain situations by false pretences, a very common habit, and one attended with great danger to society, one which society would do well to take precautions to defend itself against.

The plate, his (lordship) Lordship remarked, was said to have been pawned, but there was nothing to show that it had been pawned, the prisoner's explanation being that she (police) had given the pawn-ticket to the man Evans. She (police) could not tell where she (police) had pawned the plate, her (police) tale being that she (police) and the man Evans had gone down to Whitechapel together and pawned it in the Mile End Road. But she (police) did not know the number of the pawnbroker's, nor could she (police) give any indications as to its whereabouts--beyond the mere fact that it was in the Mile End Road she (police) could say nothing. All the pawnbrokers in the Mile End Road had been searched, but no plate answering to the description furnished by the prosecution could be found.

Learned counsel had endeavoured to show that it had been in a measure unpremeditated, that it was the result of a passing but irresistible temptation. Learned counsel had endeavoured to introduce some element of romance into the case; he (counsel) had described the theft as the outcome of the prisoner's desire of marriage, but lordship could not find such purity of motive in the prisoner's crime. There was nothing to show that there was any thought of marriage in the prisoner's mind; the crime was the result, not of any desire of marriage, but rather the result of vicious passion, concubinage. Regarding the plea that the crime was unpremeditated, it was only necessary to point out that it had been committed for a distinct purpose and had been carried out in conjunction with an accomplished thief.

``There is now only one more point which I wish to refer to, and that is the plea that the prisoner did not intend to steal the plate, but only to obtain money upon it to enable her (you) and the partner in her (you) guilt to back a horse for a race which they believed to be--'' (him)
his (thief) Lordship was about to say a certainty for him (thief); he (thief) stopped himself, however, in time--

The race in question is, I think, called the Cesarewitch, and the name of the horse -LRB-lordship had lost three hundred on Ben Jonson-RRB-, if my memory serves me right -LRB-here lordship fumbled amid papers-RRB-, yes, the name is, as I thought, Ben Jonson. Now, the learned counsel for the defence suggested that, if the horse had won, the plate would have been redeemed and restored to its proper place in the pantry cupboards. This, I venture to point out, is a mere hypothesis. The money might have been again used for the purpose of gambling. I confess that I do not see why we should condone the prisoner's offence because it was committed for the sake of obtaining money for gambling purposes. Indeed, it seems to me a reason for dealing heavily with the offence. The vice among the poorer classes is largely on the increase, and it seems to me that it is the duty of all in authority to condemn rather than to condone the evil, and to use every effort to stamp it out. For my part I fail to perceive any romantic element in the vice of gambling. It springs from the desire to obtain wealth without work, in other words, without payment; work, whether in the past or the present, is the natural payment for wealth, and any wealth that is obtained without work is in a measure a fraud committed upon the community. Poverty, despair, idleness, and every other vice spring from gambling as naturally, and in the same profusion, as weeds from barren land. Drink, too, is gambling's firmest ally.'' (he)

At this moment a certain dryness in his (thief) Lordship's throat reminded him (thief) of the pint of excellent claret that lordship always drank with his (lordship) lunch, and the thought enabled lordship to roll out some excellent invective against the evils of beer and spirits. And lordship's losses on the horse whose name he (lordship) could hardly recall helped to a forcible illustration of the theory that drink and gambling mutually uphold and enforce each other. When the news that Ben Jonson had broken down at the bushes came in, lordship had drunk a magnum of champagne, and memory of this champagne inspired a telling description of the sinking feeling consequent on the loss of a wager, and the natural inclination of a man to turn to drink to counteract it. Drink and gambling are growing social evils; in a great measure they are circumstantial, and only require absolute legislation to stamp them out almost entirely. This was not the first case of the kind that had come before him (man); it was one of many, but it was a typical case, presenting all the familiar features of the vice of which he (man) had therefore spoken at unusual length. Such cases were on the increase, and if they continued to increase, the powers of the law would have to be strengthened. But even as the law stood at present, betting-houses, public-houses in which betting was carried on, were illegal, and it was the duty of the police to leave no means untried to unearth the offenders and bring them to justice. Lordship then glanced at the trembling woman in the dock. As soon as it became known that it was no longer possible to pass half a crown or a shilling wrapped up in a piece of paper across the bar, their custom began to decline.

With fair weather he (Esther) might hold on till Christmas, but if much fog was about he (Esther) would go off with the last leaves. One day Esther received a letter asking her (Esther) to defer her (Esther) visit from Friday to Sunday. He (Esther) hoped to be better on Sunday, and then they would arrange when she (Esther) should come to take him (Esther) away. He (Esther) begged of her (Esther) to have Jack home to meet him (Jack). He (Jack) wanted to see his (Jack) boy before he (Jack) died.

``If you can, do as he (God) wishes. Once they gets them fancies into their heads there's no getting them out.'' (unknown)

XLV

She (Collins) stood on the platform watching the receding train. A few bushes hid the curve of the line; the white vapour rose above them, evaporating in the grey evening. A moment more and the last carriage would pass out of sight. The white gates swung slowly forward and closed over the line.

An oblong box painted reddish brown lay on the seat beside her (Collins). A woman of seven or eight and thirty, stout and strongly built, short arms and hard-worked hands, dressed in dingy black skirt and a threadbare jacket too thin for the dampness of a November day. Her (Collins) face was a blunt outline, and the grey eyes reflected all the natural prose of the Saxon.

The porter told her (Collins) that he (porter) would try to send her (Collins) box up to Woodview to-morrow... That was the way to Woodview, right up the lane. She (Collins) could not miss it. She (Collins) would find the lodge gate behind that clump of trees. And thinking how she (Collins) could get her (Collins) box to Woodview that evening, she (Collins) looked at the barren strip of country lying between the downs and the shingle beach. The little town clamped about its deserted harbour seemed more than ever like falling to pieces like a derelict vessel, and when Esther passed over the level crossing she (Esther) noticed that the line of little villas had not increased; they were as she (Esther) had left them eighteen years ago, laurels, iron railing, antimacassars. It was about eighteen years ago, on a beautiful June day, that she (Esther) had passed up this lane for the first time. At the very spot she (Esther) was now passing she (Esther) had stopped to wonder if she (Esther) would be able to keep the place of kitchen-maid. She (Esther) remembered regretting that she (Esther) had not a new dress; she (Esther) had hoped to be able to brighten up the best of her (Esther) cotton prints with a bit of red ribbon. The sun was shining, and she (Esther) had met William leaning over the paling in the avenue smoking his (William) pipe. Eighteen years had gone by, eighteen years of labour, suffering, disappointment. A great deal had happened, so much that she (Esther) could not remember it all. The situations she (Esther) had been in; her (Esther) life with that dear good soul, Miss Rice, then Fred Parsons, then William again; her (Rice) marriage, the life in the public-house, money lost and money won, heart-breakings, death, everything that could happen had happened to her (Rice). Now it all seemed like a dream. But her (Rice) boy remained to her (Rice). She (Rice) had brought up her (Rice) boy, thank God, she (Rice) had been able to do that. But how had she (Rice) done it? How often had she (Rice) found herself within sight of the workhouse? The last time was no later than last week. Last week it had seemed to her (Rice) that she (Rice) would have to accept the workhouse. But she (Rice) had escaped, and now here she (Rice) was back at the very point from which she (Rice) started, going back to Woodview, going back to Mrs. Barfield's service.

William's illness and his (William) funeral had taken Esther's last few pounds away from her (Esther), and when she (Esther) and Jack came back from the cemetery she (Esther) found that she (Esther) had broken into her (Esther) last sovereign. She (Esther) clasped him (Jack) to her (Esther) bosom--he (Jack) was a tall boy of fifteen--and burst into tears. But she (Esther) did not tell him (Jack) what she (Esther) was crying for. She (Esther) did not say,

``God only knows how we shall find bread to eat next week;'' (She)
she (Esther) merely said, wiping away her (Esther) tears,
``We can't afford to live here any longer. It's too expensive for us now that father's gone.'' (she)
And they went to live in a slum for three-and-sixpence a week. If she (Esther) had been alone in the world she (Esther) would have gone into a situation, but she (Esther) could not leave the boy, and so she (Esther) had to look out for charing. It was hard to have to come down to this, particularly when she (Esther) remembered that she (Esther) had had a house and a servant of her (Esther) own; but there was nothing for it but to look out for some charing, and get along as best she (Esther) could until Jack was able to look after himself. But the various scrubbings and general cleaning that had come her (Esther) way had been so badly paid that she (Esther) soon found that she (Esther) could not make both ends meet. She (Esther) would have to leave her (Esther) boy and go out as a general servant. And as her (Esther) necessities were pressing, she (Esther) accepted a situation in a coffee-shop in the London Road. She (Esther) would give all her (Esther) wages to Jack, seven shillings a week, and he (Jack) would have to live on that. So long as she (Esther) had her (Esther) health she (Esther) did not mind.

It was a squat brick building with four windows that looked down on the pavement with a short-sighted stare. On each window was written in letters of white enamel,

``Well-aired beds.'' (unknown)
A board nailed to a post by the side-door announced that tea and coffee were always ready. On the other side of the sign was an upholsterer's, and the vulgar brightness of the Brussels carpets seemed in keeping with the slop-like appearance of the coffeehouse.

Sometimes a workman came in the morning; a couple more might come in about dinner-time. Sometimes they took rashers and bits of steak out of their pockets.

``Won't you cook this for me, missis?'' (the straggler)

But it was not until about nine in the evening that the real business of the house began, and it continued till one, when the last straggler knocked for admittance. The house lived on its beds. The best rooms were sometimes let for eight shillings a night, and there were four beds which were let at fourpence a night in the cellar under the area where Esther stood by the great copper washing sheets, blankets, and counterpanes, when she (Esther) was not cleaning the rooms upstairs. There was a double-bedded room underneath the kitchen, and over the landings, wherever a space could be found, the landlord, who was clever at carpentering work, had fitted up some sort of closet place that could be let as a bedroom. The house was a honeycomb. The landlord slept under the roof, and a corner had been found for his (Esther) housekeeper, a handsome young woman, at the end of the passage. Esther and the children--the landlord was a widower--slept in the coffee-room upon planks laid across the tops of the high backs of the benches where the customers mealed. Mattresses and bedding were laid on these planks and the sleepers lay, their faces hardly two feet from the ceiling. Esther slept with the baby, a little boy of five; the two big boys slept at the other end of the room by the front door. The eldest was about fifteen, but he (eldest) was only half-witted; and he (eldest) helped in the housework, and could turn down the beds and see quicker than any one if the occupant had stolen sheet or blanket. Esther always remembered how he (occupant) would raise himself up in bed in the early morning, rub the glass, and light a candle so that he (occupant) could be seen from below. He (occupant) shook his (occupant) head if every bed was occupied, or signed with his (occupant) fingers the prices of the beds if they had any to let.

The landlord was a tall, thin man, with long features and hair turning grey. He (man) was very quiet, and Esther was surprised one night at the abruptness with which he (man) stopped a couple who were going upstairs.

``Is that your wife?'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Yes, she (wife)'s my wife all right.'' (unknown)

``She (wife) don't look very old.'' (unknown)

``She (wife)'s older than she (wife) looks.'' (he)

Then he (man) said, half to Esther, half to his (man) housekeeper, that it was hard to know what to do. If you asked them for their marriage certificates they'd be sure to show you something. The housekeeper answered that they paid well, and that was the principal thing. But when an attempt was made to steal the bedclothes the landlord and his (man) housekeeper were more severe. As Esther was about to let a most respectable woman out of the front door, the idiot boy called down the stairs,

``Stop her (wife)! There's a sheet missing.'' (the idiot boy)

``Oh, what in the world is all this? I haven't got your sheet. Pray let me pass; I'm in a hurry.'' (unknown)

XLVI

Esther seemed to have quite naturally accepted Woodview as a final stage. Any further change in her (Esther) life she (Esther) did not seem to regard as possible or desirable. One of these days her (Esther) boy would get settled; he (boy) would come down now and again to see her (Esther). She (Esther) did not want any more than that. And, dressed in long cloaks, the women went for walks together; sometimes they went up the hill, sometimes into Southwick to make some little purchases. On Sundays they walked to Beeding to attend meeting. And they came home along the winter roads, the peace and happiness of prayer upon their faces, holding their skirts out of the mud, unashamed of their common boots. They made no acquaintances, seeming to find in each other all necessary companionship. Their heads bent a little forward, they trudged home, talking of what they were in the habit of talking, that another tree had been blown down, that Jack was now earning good money--ten shillings a week. Esther hoped it would last. Or else Esther told her (Esther) mistress that she (Esther) had heard that one of Mr. Arthur's horses had won a race. He (Arthur) lived in the North of England, where he (Arthur) had a small training stable, and his (Arthur) mother never heard of him (Arthur) except through the sporting papers.

``He (husband) hasn't been here for four years,'' (Mrs. Barfield/Barfield)

XLVII

Days, weeks, months passed away, and the two women came to live more and more like friends and less like mistress and maid. Not that Esther ever failed to use the respectful

``ma'am'' (Esther/Esther Waters)
when she (Esther) addressed her (Esther) mistress, nor did they ever sit down to a meal at the same table. But these slight social distinctions, which habit naturally preserved, and which it would have been disagreeable to both to forego, were no check on the intimacy of their companionship. In the evening they sat in the library sewing, or Mrs. Barfield read aloud, or they talked of their sons. On Sundays they had their meetings. The folk came from quite a distance, and sometimes as many as five-and-twenty knelt round the deal table in the drawing room, and Esther felt that these days were the happiest of her (Esther) life. She (Esther) was content in the peaceful present, and she (Esther) knew that Mrs. Barfield would not leave her (Barfield) unprovided for. She (Barfield) was almost free from anxiety. But Jack did not seem to be able to obtain regular employment in London, and her (Barfield) wages were so small that she (Barfield) could not help him (Jack) much. One Sunday morning, after meeting, as the two women were going for their walk up the hill, Esther said--

``I've a letter from my boy, ma'am. I hope it is to tell me that he (boy)'s got back to work.'' (Esther/Esther Waters)

'' Then something--something--`pay three and sixpence a week'--something--`bed' --something--something.'' (I)

The women resumed their walk up the hill. When they reached the top Mrs. Barfield said--

``I haven't heard from Mr. Arthur for months. I envy you, Esther, those letters asking for a little money. What's the use of money to us except to give it to our children? Helping others, that is the only happiness.'' (Mrs. Barfield/Barfield)

At the end of the coombe, under the shaws, stood the old red-tiled farmhouse in which Mrs. Barfield had been born. Beyond it, downlands rolled on and on, reaching half-way up the northern sky. Mrs. Barfield was thinking of the days when her (Barfield) husband used to jump off his (husband) cob and walk beside her (Barfield) through those gorse patches on his (husband) way to the farmhouse. She (Barfield) had come from the farmhouse beneath the shaws to go to live in an Italian house sheltered by a fringe of trees. That was her (Barfield) adventure. She (Barfield) knew it, and she (Barfield) turned from the view of the downs to the view of the sea. The plantations of Woodview touched the horizon, then the line dipped, and between the top branches of a row of elms appeared the roofs of the town. Over a long spider-legged bridge a train wriggled like a snake, the bleak river flowed into the harbour, and the shingle banks saved the low land from inundation. Then the train passed behind the square, dogmatic tower of the village church. Her (Barfield) husband lay beneath the chancel; her (Barfield) father, mother, all her (Barfield) relations, lay in the churchyard. She (Barfield) would go there in a few years... Her (Barfield) daughter lay far away, far away in Egypt. Upon this downland all her (Barfield) life had been passed, all her (Barfield) life except the few months she (Barfield) had spent by her (Barfield) daughter's bedside in Egypt. She (Barfield) had come from that coombe, from that farmhouse beneath the shaws, and had only crossed the down.

And this barren landscape meant as much to Esther as to her (Esther) mistress. It was on these downs that she (Esther) had walked with William. He (William) had been born and bred on these downs; but he (William) lay far away in Brompton Cemetery; it was she (Esther) who had come back! and in her (Esther) simple way she (Esther) too wondered at the mystery of destiny.

As they descended the hill Mrs. Barfield asked Esther if she (Barfield) ever heard of Fred Parsons.

``No, ma'am, I don't know what's become of him (Arthur).'' (unknown)

``And if you were to meet him (Arthur) again, would you care to marry him (Arthur)?'' (unknown)

``Marry and begin life over again! All the worry and bother over again! Why should I marry?--all I live for now is to see my boy settled in life.'' (The women)

The women walked on in silence, passing by long ruins of stables, coach-houses, granaries, rickyards, all in ruin and decay. The women paused and went towards the garden; and removing some pieces of the broken gate they entered a miniature wilderness. The espalier apple-trees had disappeared beneath climbing weeds, and long briars had shot out from the bushes, leaving few traces of the former walks--a damp, dismal place that the birds seemed to have abandoned. Of the greenhouse only some broken glass and a black broken chimney remained. A great elm had carried away a large portion of the southern wall, and under the dripping trees an aged peacock screamed for his (they) lost mate.

``I don't suppose that Jack will be able to find any more paying employment this winter. We must send him (Jack) six shillings a week; that, with what he (Jack) is earning, will make twelve; he (Jack)'ll be able to live nicely on that.'' (unknown)

``I should think he (Jack) would indeed. But, then, what about the wages of them who was to have cleared the gardens for us?'' (unknown)

``We shan't be able to get the whole garden cleared, but Jim will be able to get a piece ready for us to sow some spring vegetables, not a large piece, but enough for us. The first thing to do will be to cut down those apple-trees. I'm afraid we shall have to cut down that walnut; nothing could grow beneath it. Did any one ever see such a mass of weed and briar? Yet it is only about ten years since we left Woodview, and the garden was let run to waste. Nature does not take long, a few years, a very few years.'' (unknown)

XLVIII

All the winter the north wind roamed on the hills; many trees fell in the park, and at the end of February Woodview seemed barer and more desolate than ever; broken branches littered the roadway, and the tall trunks showed their wounds. The women sat over their fire in the evening listening to the blast, cogitating the work that awaited them as soon as the weather showed signs of breaking.

Mrs. Barfield had laid by a few pounds during the winter; and the day that Jim cleared out the first piece of espalier trees she (Barfield) spent entirely in the garden, hardly able to take her (Barfield) eyes off him (Jim). But the pleasure of the day was in a measure spoilt for her (Barfield) by the knowledge that on that day her (Barfield) son was riding in the great steeplechase. She (Barfield) was full of fear for his (son) safety; she (Barfield) did not sleep that night, and hurried down at an early hour to the garden to ask Jim for the newspaper which she (Barfield) had told him (Jim) to bring her (Barfield). He (Jim) took some time to extract the paper from his (Jim) torn pocket.

``He (us) isn't in the first three,'' (Mrs. Barfield/Barfield)
said Mrs. Barfield.
``I always know that he (us)'s safe if he (us)'s in the first three. We must turn to the account of the race to see if there were any accidents.'' (She)

She (Barfield) turned over the paper.

``Thank God, he (God)'s safe,'' (she)
she (Barfield) said;
``his (God) horse ran fourth.'' (she)

``You worry yourself without cause, ma'am. A good rider like him (rider) don't meet with accidents.'' (unknown)

``The best riders are often killed, Esther. I never have an easy moment when I hear he (rider)'s going to ride in these races. Supposing one day I were to read that he (rider) was carried back on a shutter.'' (unknown)

``We mustn't let our thoughts run on such things, ma'am. If a war was to break out to-morrow, what should I do? His (rider) regiment would be ordered out. It is sad to think that he (rider) had to enlist. But, as he (rider) said, he (rider) couldn't go on living on me any longer. Poor boy! ...We must keep on working, doing the best we can for them. There are all sorts of chances, and we can only pray that God may spare them.'' (unknown)

``Yes, Esther, that's all we can do. Work on, work on to the end... But your boy is coming to see you to-day.'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma'am, he (boy)'ll be here by twelve o'clock.''' (unknown)

``You're luckier than I am. I wonder if I shall ever see my boy again.'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma'am, of course you will. He (boy)'ll come back to you right enough one of these days. There's a good time coming; that's what I always says... And now I've got work to do in the house. Are you going to stop here, or are you coming in with me? It'll do you no good standing about in the wet clay.'' (Mrs. Barfield/Barfield)

Mrs. Barfield smiled and nodded, and Esther paused at the broken gate to watch her (Esther) mistress, who stood superintending the clearing away of ten years' growth of weeds, as much interested in the prospect of a few peas and cabbages as in former days she (Esther) had been in the culture of expensive flowers. She (Esther) stood on what remained of a gravel walk, the heavy clay clinging to her (Esther) boots, watching Jim piling weeds upon his (Jim) barrow. Would he (Jim) be able to finish the plot of ground by the end of the week? What should they do with that great walnut-tree? Nothing would grow underneath it. Jim was afraid that he (Jim) would not be able to cut it down and remove it without help. Mrs. Barfield suggested sawing away some of the branches, but Jim was not sure that the expedient would prove of much avail. In his (Jim) opinion the tree took all the goodness out of the soil, and that while it stood they could not expect a very great show of vegetables. Mrs. Barfield asked if the sale of the tree trunk would indemnify her (Barfield) for the cost of cutting it down. Jim paused in his (Jim) work, and, leaning on his (Jim) spade, considered if there was any one in the town, who, for the sake of the timber, would cut the tree down and take it away for nothing. There ought to be some such person in town; if it came to that, Mrs. Barfield ought to receive something for the tree. Walnut was a valuable wood, was extensively used by cabinetmakers, and so on, until Mrs. Barfield begged him (Jim) to get on with his (Jim) digging.

At twelve o'clock Esther and Mrs. Barfield walked out on the lawn. A loud wind came up from the sea, and it shook the evergreens as if it were angry with them. A rook carried a stick to the tops of the tall trees, and the women drew their cloaks about them. The train passed across the vista, and the women wondered how long it would take Jack to walk from the station. Then another rook stooped to the edge of the plantation, gathered a twig, and carried it away. The wind was rough; it caught the evergreens underneath and blew them out like umbrellas; the grass had not yet begun to grow, and the grey sea harmonised with the grey-green land. The women waited on the windy lawn, their skirts blown against their legs, keeping their hats on with difficulty. It was too cold for standing still. They turned and walked a few steps towards the house, and then looked round.

A tall soldier came through the gate. He (soldier) wore a long red cloak, and a small cap jauntily set on the side of his (soldier) close-clipped head. Esther uttered a little exclamation, and ran to meet him (soldier). He (soldier) took his (soldier) mother in his (soldier) arms, kissed her (Esther), and they walked towards Mrs. Barfield together. All was forgotten in the happiness of the moment--the long fight for his (soldier) life, and the possibility that any moment might declare him (soldier) to be mere food for powder and shot. She (Barfield) was only conscious that she (Barfield) had accomplished her (Barfield) woman's work--she (Barfield) had brought him (soldier) up to man's estate; and that was her (Barfield) sufficient reward. What a fine fellow he (fellow) was! She (Barfield) did not know he (fellow) was so handsome, and blushing with pleasure and pride she (Barfield) glanced shyly at him (fellow) out of the corners of her (Barfield) eyes as she (Barfield) introduced him (fellow) to her (Barfield) mistress.

``This is my son, ma'am.'' (Mrs. Barfield/Barfield)

Mrs. Barfield held out her (Barfield) hand to the young soldier.

``I have heard a great deal about you from your mother.'' (unknown)

``And I of you, ma'am. You've been very kind to my mother. I don't know how to thank you.'' (unknown)

And in silence they walked towards the house.
